author: normj
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

We are looking into how we can support adding a AWS Lambda Function to the `DistributedApplicationBuilder`. A Lambda function can be written as an executable or as a class library. The class library programming model being the more common approach.

The executable approach is not an issue for Aspire but for the class library we need to customize the execution arguments. Lambda functions coded as a class library are started with a host executable and the depsfile and runtimeconfig are overriden at startup. The class library is passed in as an argument to the host executable. For example if we had .NET project called "ClassLibraryLambdaFunction" that contained a Lambda function it would be executed using the following:

```
dotnet exec --depsfile ./ClassLibraryLambdaFunction.deps.json --runtimeconfig ./ClassLibraryLambdaFunction.runtimeconfig.json ../../../../AspireExtensions/LambdaHost/Amazon.Lambda.RuntimeSupport.dll ClassLibraryLambdaFunction::ClassLibraryLambdaFunction.Function::FunctionHandler
```

Having this configured in the launchSettings.json file by the user is not practical and as part of an `AddAWSLambdaFunction` method I want to be able to setup all of these command line arguments for the user and return a LambdaProjectResource that is a subclass of ProjectResource. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

When adding project to the `DistributedApplicationBuilder` you can only specify the launchSettings profile name for configuring how the project should be started. I would like to propose adding a **LaunchSettingsOverrideAnnotation** annotation where all of the command line arguments for the "dotnet" command can be specified. The [ApplicationExecutor](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/07f1f34dd5c0b7bf5f1f3294cbcc9965af218b91/src/Aspire.Hosting/Dcp/ApplicationExecutor.cs#L1058) would look for the annotation and if exists use it for setting up the parameters for the process.

### Update February 2nd, 2025

The issue has gotten long and a bit off the original ask. We currently have a work around by writing a launchsettings profile during Aspire startup that matches the arguments set in the AppHost plus other settings to launch a class library. The work around works but it feels hacky to write to the launchsettings.json file which will cause users to change files.

The ideal solution for us is to have APIs as part of Aspire that essentially defines a launch profile in memory and hand that off to either the `dotnet run` or the IDE depending on whether Aspire has an IDE attached to it. I understand that is a larger task because it requires changes to the protocol for Aspire to talk to the IDE.

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
@normj - have you considered making the "class library" `dotnet run`-able? This can be done by adding MSBuild logic to set 

* RunCommand
* RunArguments

See https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/blob/f7a5c4e3dc7f7ac35a2684192413530a43877a05/src/Tasks/Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks/targets/Microsoft.NET.Sdk.targets#L1111-L1171

These MSBuild properties are used by `dotnet run` and by VS (and thus by the Aspire AppHost) to launch projects.

In .NET 9, we added functionality to allow MSBuild `<Target>`s to set these properties, so you can run any logic to determine these values. See [Extend `dotnet run` to invoke a run-command-producing Target (dotnet/sdk#42240)](https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/42240).

nodes.author: normj
nodes.body:

I do have the challenge that within a class library there could me multiple Lambda functions that need to be started up separately with different argument to identity the .NET method to call. Imagine in an Aspire AppHost the same project being added multiple times to the distributed application but with a different "handler" string that identifies what method to call. Maybe what I could do is have the MSBuild targets for running the class library look at an environment variable that the Aspire AppHost sets on the process. I'll play around and see what I can do.

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
> If this was launched via the IDE would the IDE attach the debugger to it?

Yes. That is my understanding (although I have much less experience in the IDE tooling parts). 

Look at the `'$(UseAppHost)' != 'true'` path:

https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/blob/f7a5c4e3dc7f7ac35a2684192413530a43877a05/src/Tasks/Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks/targets/Microsoft.NET.Sdk.targets#L1134-L1138

```xml
        <RunCommand Condition="'$(RunCommand)' == ''">dotnet</RunCommand>

        <_NetCoreRunArguments>exec "$(TargetPath)"</_NetCoreRunArguments>
        <RunArguments Condition="'$(RunArguments)' == '' and '$(StartArguments)' != ''">$(_NetCoreRunArguments) $(StartArguments)</RunArguments>
        <RunArguments Condition="'$(RunArguments)' == ''">$(_NetCoreRunArguments)</RunArguments>
```

This is basically the same thing you have. `dotnet exec <some .dll>`

nodes.author: normj
nodes.body:
You can reproduce the error using my Lambda Aspire proof of concept (POC). It doesn't require an AWS account or credentials to run. The POC was made back in September and using a class library worked using the launchsettings.json file. We are picking the project back up now turning the POC into a real product and now using the latest bits the class library no longer seems to work.

To repo:
* Clone https://github.com/normj/LambdaAspirePOC
* checkout branch **classlibrary-failure**
* In VS launch the AppHost
* Notice the PID for `ToLowerLambdaFunction` project resource is 0 and there is nothing written to the logs. My guess is Aspire didn't even try to run the project because the output type was not an executable. Similar to the error we saw when using `dotnet run` complaining about the output type. "A runnable project should target a runnable TFM (for instance, net5.0) and have OutputType 'Exe'."

What is supposed to happen is the `ClassLibraryLambdaFunction` project has a profile in the `launchSettings.json` that provides the actual executable entry point that should be used. 
```
{
  "profiles": {
    "LambdaRuntimeClient_FunctionHandler": {
      "commandName": "Executable",
      "commandLineArgs": "exec --depsfile ./ClassLibraryLambdaFunction.deps.json --runtimeconfig ./ClassLibraryLambdaFunction.runtimeconfig.json ../../../../AspireExtensions/LambdaHost/Amazon.Lambda.RuntimeSupport.dll ClassLibraryLambdaFunction::ClassLibraryLambdaFunction.Function::FunctionHandler",
      "workingDirectory": ".\\bin\\$(Configuration)\\net8.0",
      "executablePath": "dotnet"
    }
  }
}
```

In the `AddAWSLambdaFunction` extension method you can see I set the launch setting profile. https://github.com/normj/LambdaAspirePOC/blob/classlibrary-failure/AspireExtensions/Aspire.Hosting.AWS.Lambda/LambdaExtensions.cs#L22

If you make the `ClassLibraryLambdaFunction` the startup project you can confirm the profile actually starts up till you get an expected error about "Invalid URI". Through the AppHost it makes sure that URI is correctly set up.

Keep in mind my ultimate goal and the original reason for this issue is I want to get rid of dealing with the launchsettings.json file and from my `AddAWSLambdaFunction` extension method tell Aspire all of the command line arguments needed to run the class library.

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
> Keep in mind my ultimate goal and the original reason for this issue is I want to get rid of dealing with the launchsettings.json file

The best way to do this is to make the project `dotnet run`-able. We did just that for Azure Functions support in 9.0. Check out:

https://github.com/Azure/azure-functions-dotnet-worker/blob/6338dc2e08d04a78956dd48dd6738888ab215bde/sdk/Sdk/Targets/Microsoft.Azure.Functions.Worker.Sdk.targets#L83-L90

```xml
  <!-- This target is used to set up the run arguments for the function app, supporting `dotnet run` -->
  <Target Name="_FunctionsComputeRunArguments" BeforeTargets="ComputeRunArguments">
    <PropertyGroup>
      <RunCommand>func</RunCommand>
      <RunArguments>host start $(RunArguments)</RunArguments>
      <RunWorkingDirectory>$(OutDir)</RunWorkingDirectory>
    </PropertyGroup>
  </Target>
```

You don't even need to use the `ComputeRunArguments` target if the RunCommand and RunArguments are static - you can just set the properties directly in a `.targets` file.

Set the executable project as the startup project."}

If there is a way to get the RunCommand and RunArguments be honored via launching in Visual Studio and the project is attached to the debugger that would give me a great working path. The `launchsettings.json` path isn't not the right long term solution for us.

nodes.author: tlmii
nodes.body:
@normj I can repro the problem with your repo above (thanks for making that easy!) and I can see what appears to be the issue, including the change that caused it. 

Trying to track down the reason for the change (it appears to have been a bug fix in coordinating profile information between DCP and the IDE) to determine the best path forward. More soon...

nodes.author: normj
nodes.body: @tlmii Thanks for the update

nodes.author: tlmii
nodes.body:
We're pretty sure we've identified the fix and have [the first](https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/45497) of a couple PRs out needed to flow it through to VS. There's an issue with the API definition between DCP and the IDE that has been there for a while, but it was only exposed recently when another fix was made in VS to more closely adhere to the [rules in the spec](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/main/docs/specs/IDE-execution.md#launch-profile-processing-project-launch-configuration) around the invocation arguments.

At the moment I'm not aware of a workaround. @karolz-ms would there be any way to force DCP to pass these same arguments so that VS effectively overrides them with themselves? Obviously it'd be a short term hack, but just until we were able to flow the real fix to a public/preview build?

nodes.author: normj
nodes.body: Thanks for the update @tlmii. Trying to understand what is going on the PR. The arguments in being talked about in the PR are the commandline arguments specified in the `launchSettings.json` file? Looking at the spec and the code for `Aspire.Hosting` it doesn't look like the application model has been expanded for Aspire resources to be able to specify the command line arguments which is my ideal solution.

nodes.author: tlmii
nodes.body:
Hey @normj - in the PR description when I mention the user-specified command line arguments, I mean the ones in launchsettings.json. The invocation arguments (`args` in the API definition that we are changing in that PR) are arguments that can override those in the launch profile, if specified. They are passed from DCP to the IDE as part of the run session request.

I'm not sure what populates the invocation arguments. You may well be right that there's nothing in the API to do so. I was just hoping Karol might know of a way to finesse it to pass what you need in the short term, even if definitely not something you'd do long term. Otherwise I don't think we have a workaround (from this angle at least) until the fixes flow through.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
I think that @normj is right; there does not seem to be a way to override Executable invocation arguments in app host code. What Norm proposed originally (an annotation to override invocation arguments) makes a lot of sense to me.

@mitchdenny toughts?

nodes.author: tlmii

Apologies that we didn't come up with a way to get that to you earlier or find a workaround in the interim; but hopefully not too much longer until you're unblocked.

After syncing with @davidfowl about our needs to be able to control all of the command line arguments from Aspire. We are able to get the profile to the IDE but after updating Visual Studio 2022 preview today it broke the ability to debug class libraries again despite. We are getting this error message in the Aspire console window. I have confirmed if I make the class library the startup project and select the launch profile we generated it will launch correctly. But from the Aspire IDE integration it looks like there is some validation logic blocking despite how we configure the launch profile.

> {"name":"MultiplyFunction-fzjneyws"}, "Reconciliation": 6, "Status": "500 Internal Server Error", "Body": "A project with an Output Type of Class Library cannot be started directly.\r\n\r\nIn order to debug this project, add an executable project to this solution which references the library project. Set the executable project as the startup project."}

### Is there an existing issue for this?

### Describe the bug

This is what is displayed for a health check that is validates whether an endpoint returns 200:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c10884d5-8566-45ae-a246-bc2de2c20d17)

No message is returned so health checks defaults to displaying the exception message. This doesn't look user friendly.

The health check should have a failure message like "Request to xxx timed out" if there is a timeout.  Or "Request to xxx returned yyy status code".

We should do the same for other built-in checks: polling an endpoint for 200, a database for a good response, or message queue, etc. The failure message message should explain what has gone wrong in a friendly way. author: JamesNK
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Resource detail has a bunch of sections:

* Resource properties
* Endpoints
* Volumes
* Health checks
* Env vars
* Relationships (future?)
* Wait for (future? - could be part of relationships)

Today they're almost all always shown (one exception is `Volumes` which is hardcoded to only shown for containers).

Always showing these sections is noisey and can be strange for custom resources where these things are never valid. For example, a Postgres database resource is never going to have endpoints, volumes, env vars, etc.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/31d4a1e6-1224-4d5c-98d6-5a71b1e4a6bb)



### Describe the solution you'd like

There should be a difference between "I don't have an endpoint", e.g. a .NET worker app, and "I don't support endpoints", e.g. a postgres database resource.

Perhaps there should be fields on a resource to say if it can have these things, e.g. `is_endpoints_supported`, `is_volumes_supported`. That data can be used to control these visibility of sections.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body:
Alternatively we could continue to hardcode in the dashboard:

* Volumes are only visible in containers
* Env vars are only visible in containers, exes, projects
* Endpoints are only visible in containers, exes, projects

I'm not sure about endpoints. Technically someone could start kestrel inside the app host and have the custom resource expose an endpoint that way.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
> Env vars are only visible in containers, exes, projects

IResourceWithEnvironment determines when this shows up in the app model. We should mirror capabilities in the resource server protocol.

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body: If we based it on the resource capabilities, does it concern you that someone could use `ResourceNotificationService` to add env vars (or any other data they wanted) to a snapshot but not have the env vars returned to the dashboard?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
> If we based it on the resource capabilities, does it concern you that someone could use ResourceNotificationService to add env vars (or any other data they wanted) to a snapshot but not have the env vars returned to the dashboard?

It does concern me 😄, but that would be a change to our model.

title: Add a way for a resource to hide sections in resource details

author: JamesNK
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Visiting the console logs page causes Aspire to load logs. For DCP resources, the host calls DCP get to get its old logs, streaming them from beginning to end, and then continuing to stream new logs as they arrive.

The problem with this the order doesn't match what is shown in the Aspire. Aspire wants to shows the latest logs by default, with a scrollbar to go back and view older logs.

By streaming logs from the beginning, the UI rapidly updates as it quickly tries to render logs from beginning to end, causing the UI to freeze, lock up, and generally behave badly. A resource with 10,000 logs does a lot of UI updates for lines 1-9900 before 9901-10000 are actually displayed.

### Expected Behavior

Ideally:

1. The dashboard quickly displays the latest logs.
2. The dashboard streams new logs as they arrive.
3. The dashboard loads historical logs in the background.

A couple of solutions I see:

1. The current DCP method to get console logs is tweaked:
    1. Add a parameter to limit the amount of historical logs returned. The dashboard never attempts to show more than 10,000 logs in the past so this could be passed to provide an upper limit on the amount of data DCP attempts to return.
    2. The DCP method adds a header with a count of the current number of logs available. This could be used by Aspire to display a loading indicator in logs. The console logs wouldn't start being displayed until the amount of lines received from DCP equals this line count. This change would stop the UI from trying to display older logs as they're returned. The downside is there would be a delay while displaying the loading indicator as old logs are loaded.

2. Another option would be for there to be two calls to get log data from DCP:
    1. One call to stream the last 100 logs, plus new logs. This call would need to return a total log count in the header so the line number is accurate when logs are initially displayed.
    2. Another call to stream historical logs. It would load old logs in the background.
    3. NOTE: Aspire host doesn't use the order that logs are received for ordering, just the date. Theoritically there could be one API call that simulatanously returns logs from newest to oldest while at the same time returning latest logs.

I think option 1 is probably easy both from hosting and DCP perspective. Option 2 would create a better experience by making logs consistently load quickly.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: JamesNK

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
We definitely don't want to see the Blazor UX freeze up, nor do we want the backend of the dashboard or the apphost to eat a lot of resources just for logs that the user doesn't want to see. So anything we can do to optimize this is worthwhile.

One thing I thought about is whether we could do this work as part of adding other value to the console logging experience. For example, showing the last x log lines is really a filter function, but I am wondering if we could add text search over the logs as part of this?

The other dimension to this is that I know that @DamianEdwards and @davidfowl want to support a model where the dashboard is a persistent resource.

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body:
Text search wouldn't be difficult. Logs are in memory after loading, so the work would mostly be in the UI. But this issue is focused on loading the logs.

Dashboard as a persistent resource doesn't matter either way. The dashboard doesn't keep all logs in-memory even when it's running. Navigating away from the console logs page clears them from memory.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
@JamesNK sorry for late reply

We are a little bit constrained on DCP side in terms of what new options we can support for log streaming because of differences between Containers and Executables, and between various container engines. The following is the set of new options for log requests that can be implemented while keeping these constraints satisfied:

1. `limit=N` this would limit the logs response to N log lines. This option is compatible with `tail` and `since` (see below), but not `follow`.
2. `tail=N`limits the logs response to (at most) N EXISTING, newest log lines. If `follow` is set, new log lines that appear after the log stream was created do not count against the limit, and will be streamed until the client closes the stream. Not compatible with `since`.
3. `since=T` limits the logs response to log lines created after timestamp T. 

Unfortunately it is not possible for DCP to efficiently determine how many log lines are available for Containers. We could implement that for Executables only if that helps.

I believe the dashboard could implement efficient log retrieval by combining the "latest log" stream (`tail=page_size, follow=true`) with retrieving "previous pages" of logs on demand (`tail=reverse_page_number*page_size, limit=page_size`). Let me know please if my understanding is correct and if the `since` option makes things easier.

@danegsta @dbreshears FYI

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body:
A fundamental problem we have with console logs today is content is streamed from oldest to newest, but that is the wrong direction for the UI. In the UI we want to immediately display the newest logs.

Ideally what we want is:
1. Get logs from newest to oldest, and
2. Get new logs as they arrive

That lets the UI quickly show the latest log content, with older logs loading in over time (1), while at the same time showing new logs as they arrive (2). Perhaps there should be two calls to DCP to get this data.

Next time there is a free hard problems meeting we should discuss this area. I apprieticate there are technical limitations, so a real time discussion about what work best would be good.

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body: @karolz-ms Do you plan to make improvements here for 9.3? If so, what changes will be required in the dashboard side?

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
@JamesNK yes. The PR to add `skip`, `limit` and `tail` options to DCP is in review right now. Once it is merged and the new version of DCP is integrated with Aspire, I plan to add these API definitions to Aspire DCP client. This should be a small work item.

After this the dashboard/dashboard service can use these new capabilities to improve the logs experience along the lines you outlined in the original description for this issue. I am not sure if you/your team has any room left to do any work on this in 9.3 timeframe?

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/9593 added new log stream options to DCP API definitions in Aspire. This should make it possible for app model and dashboard to improve on the log viewing experience.

title: Bad experience when viewing console logs for a resource with a lot of logs

author: mitchdenny
body:
At the moment most hosting integrations are wired up to listen for the `ConnectionStringAvailableEvent` to capture the connection string and then stuff that value into a captured variable which is shared with the health check registration code. This code is overly cumbersome and we would like to improve it.

The main issue is that typically most of the callbacks to configure clients on the health check registration methods are synchronous which means we can't get the connection string without doing sync over async.

We've filed this issue on the repo containing a lot of the health checks we are using:

https://github.com/Xabaril/AspNetCore.Diagnostics.HealthChecks/issues/2306

That links to this PR which shows an example of the changes we are after applied to Redis:

https://github.com/Xabaril/AspNetCore.Diagnostics.HealthChecks/pull/2305
title: Simplify health check code in .NET Aspire hosting integrations.

author: davidebbo
body:
*Context: this is based on [discussions](https://discord.com/channels/732297728826277939/1281287950491193436/1292211397052207146) with @davidfowl on Discord.*

When running on Docker Desktop, there is magic allowing a container to talk to the host, by using the special hostname `host.docker.internal`. However, this is not available on all environments. e.g. it likely doesn't work in the following cases:
1. Docker in WSL (see this [StackOverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63898430/how-can-i-access-a-service-running-on-wsl2-from-inside-a-docker-container))
1. Docker engine on Windows without Docker Desktop
1. Podman
1. Docker Engine on Linux

This issue exists both for http and https traffic, but https presents an additional level of complexity. Even with Docker Desktop, it is problematic because containers don't have the self-signed cert that would allow them to talk to the host. ANd even if they did, it wouldn't work because the cert is only for `localhost`, and not `host.docker.internal`.

One potential solution is to use a reverse tunnel, similar to what @davidfowl does in https://github.com/davidfowl/YarpTunnelDemo. The trick that makes this work is that the communication is initiated from the Host to the proxy container, and not from a Container to the Host. And yet, its reverse nature effectively allows Container to Host communication, without ever needing to talk to a host port.

Here is an illustration (courtesy of @davidfowl):

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/20ed367b-e97b-4fd7-94d0-269a642e113e)

nodes.author: davidebbo
nodes.body: It would be useful if Yarp had direct support for this, as tracked by https://github.com/microsoft/reverse-proxy/issues/1618.

nodes.body:
Should me make it more clear in the docs？ 
This problem bothers me several days.

nodes.author: davidebbo

But there was no follow-up, so I'm not sure where this stands. @davidfowl should be able to give a status as to whether this is still on the roadmap, or whether there are some alternate podman workarounds.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @danegsta @karolz-ms This should bubble up to the top of the list. We've had some discussion recently about how to make this work with both non http traffic *and* https traffic (which adds a complication wrt the certs). It's also unclear if this goes into the app host or dcp..

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
@karolz-ms and I have had some discussions around what architecture we’d use to solve the problem via DCP. Basic idea was to create a proxy container that would act as one side of a tunnel to route traffic through DCP and out to the host services.

We considered something like the SOCKS protocol, but we have to establish the connection between host and container on the opposite direction of a normal proxy flow. Karol has been doing some research into various proxy libraries to see if any off the shelf implementations can already do what we need and I wrote up an initial draft of a possible SOCKS inspired protocol we could use if we needed to implement the proxy ourselves.

author: aaronpowell
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

I'm wanting to create a resource command that, when run, dumps out the model information for an Ollama model. I figured the best place to "dump" this would be to logs, but when I resolve a logger (either the `ResourceLoggerService` or the `ILogger<OllamaModelResource>`) from the service container that is available in the execution method of the resource command, the log messages end up in the console logs and not structured logs for the resource.

### Describe the solution you'd like

There should be a way to resolve a logger instance which is capable of writing to the structured logs for the resource.

This would also be useful within eventing and life cycle events to provide something that is more human parsable than the raw log stream.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Why do you need to write to structured logs?

nodes.author: aaronpowell
nodes.body:
Because it seems like the most logical place in which I would log out something that contains a complex object.

In my current solution I am able to do this:

![Ollama console logs](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/458b8571-3d6b-4c6d-9a0c-5cd6a8eadaf9)

To achieve that I'm doing `JsonSerializer.Serialize` for the list of models as it doesn't write it out any other way. But having it "hidden" in the stdout console rather than structures logs from the resource doesn't align with where I'd expect to look - other logging events from the resource should end up under the Structured tab, so why couldn't this?

nodes.author: Mrxx99
nodes.body: For this scenario it would also be nice if a resource command could open a text visualizer dialog

nodes.author: joperezr
nodes.body: Talked about this in triage. Doing it from the AppHost would probably be very hacky given there is no guarantee that the resource of the command is using .NET or Aspire to configure OTel. The best way to do this would be the command to call and endpoint into the resource, and then the resource doing the logging.

nodes.author: aaronpowell
nodes.body:
I feel like that could be a very tricky proposition for integrations where the thing is wrapping something which OTEL wouldn't make sense to be integrated with.

For the example that was the catalyst for this issue, I'm calling an endpoint on Ollama and wanting to output the information that is returned from the endpoint, so I'm not sure how you'd flip that in another approach.

title: Support writing to structured logs from resource commands

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
I believe there are two related errors here, both of which are related to how the internal host logs and rethrowing errors   
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/efdd29953304f1fc494bb45c5785d37961c4a14b/src/libraries/Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting/src/Internal/Host.cs#L151-L170

## 1. `IHost.StartAsync` Exception in Dashboard executable

The first occurs occurs if an application occurs during the Dashboard's `IHost.StartAsync()` method.  One way to reproduce this is to make the the OTLP port match the applicationUrl in your AppHost's `launchsettings.json`

```json
{
  "$schema": "https://json.schemastore.org/launchsettings.json",
  "profiles": {
    "https": {
      "commandName": "Project",
      "dotnetRunMessages": true,
      "launchBrowser": true,
      "applicationUrl": "https://localhost:17141;http://localhost:15042",
      "environmentVariables": {
        "ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development",
        "DOTNET_ENVIRONMENT": "Development",
        "DOTNET_DASHBOARD_OTLP_ENDPOINT_URL": "https://localhost:17141", // Make this match a port used in applicationUrl
        "DOTNET_RESOURCE_SERVICE_ENDPOINT_URL": "https://localhost:22138"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

When the dashboard app fails to bind to the port, the `LogAndRethrow` method in `Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting.Internal.Host` catches the exception and logs it to the logging infrastructure which in turn writes to stdout in json. 
 `DashboardLifecycleHook.WatchResourceLogsAsync()` is then able to parse this correctly.  However because the exception is also rethrown, it is not caught anywhere else and bubles up until it causes the entire app to crash with an unhandled exception.  At this point, dotnet writes the unhandled exception to stdout, which really mucks up  `DashboardLifecycleHook.WatchResourceLogsAsync()` - with each line of stdout becoming it's own log entry in the App Host console:

## 2. `IHost.StartAsync` Exception in App Host executable

If a failure occurs within `DashboardServiceHost` in the AppHost, then you get the error logged 3 times.  2 copies happen because we start one `IHost` within another.  Each host logs and then rethrows the exception causing the first 2 copies of the error.
https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/89e329c95ebac571567a58f27bfeb462d8e6b35d/src/Aspire.Hosting/Dashboard/DashboardServiceHost.cs#L201.  The 3rd copy occurs as the exception bubbles up to the `Main` method unhandled, and so the dotnet runtime blows up with an unhandled exception.

This version can be reproduced by simply running the same app host in two separate console windows:

```
dotnet run --project S:\AspireApp1\AspireApp1.AppHost\
dotnet run --project S:\AspireApp1\AspireApp1.AppHost\
```

author: Steinblock
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

The new Aspire 9 feature `ContainerLifetime.Persistant` is pretty cool to improve startup time.

The only issue I have is that the containers are still running after I close the solution in Visual Studio. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

Create a third option to destroy the container on IDE close.

```
public enum ContainerLifetime
{
    Session,
    Persistent,
    /// <summary>
    /// Attempt to re-use a previously created resource (based on the container name) if one exists. Destroy the container on IDE close.
    /// </summary>
    /// <remarks>
    Workspace,
}
```

I know this could be hard to implement because there are different IDEs to support but the process that creates the containers could possibly watch for it's parent process to be terminated to destroy the containers (Even that wouldn't be fail safe because I always can open another solution in VS or open another Directory in vscode.

But it would be a good start and it would be pretty useful to have the possibility as well.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: This is something the team has discussed. Definitely non-trivial and needs to be designed.

title: Extend ContainerLifetime enum to destroy the containers on IDE close

author: dluc
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

When using `.WithHttpEndpoint()` Aspire automatically proxies, from an HTTP endpoint to target HTTP endpoint.

When using `.WithHttpsEndpoint()` Aspire automatically proxies from an HTTPS endpoint to target HTTP endpoint. In this scenario, it leverages .NET dev cert, which is trusted, a nice to have when working with web apps locally, so the user doesn't get security alerts.

However, there is no way to have an HTTPS endpoing proxying to a target HTTP endpoint. For instance, when serving a web site and working with OAuth, one might need to use HTTPS. 

On Azure, the platform takes care of proxying from HTTPS to HTTP. 
Aspire doesn't offer the same, so one has to implement SSL locally with custom certs, to be created and configured, leading to more work. Another approach is spinning up, only locally, a reverse proxy app/container like stunnel, grok, and similar, to do that, something like this:

```csharp
var httpApp = builder
                 .AddProject<MyApp>()
                 .WithHttpEndpoint();

var httpsApp = builder.AddProject<Proxy>()
                 .WithEnvironment("TARGET_ENDPOINT", httpApp.GetEndpoint("http"))
                 .WithHttpsEndpoint();
```

### Describe the solution you'd like

Allow to map from HTTPS to HTTP, something like

```csharp
var httpsApp = builder
                 .AddProject<MyApp>()
                 .WithHttpsEndpoint(httpsTarget = false); // the internal endpoint will be http://...
```

This way, the HTTPS endpoint will leverage .NET dev cert, and the internal endpoint is a simple HTTP endpoint that doesn't require and SSL configuration.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
The proxying that Aspire does during the local dev inner loop today is TCP-level, not HTTP level, so it can't easily proxy from HTTPS to HTTP. There are other issues covering HTTP ingress and better support for HTTPS using the dev cert though that would likely improve your scenario:

- #5508
- #836
- #4319
- #5453
- #6890

title: Allow to proxy from HTTPS to HTTP

author: DamianEdwards
body:
Some of the Aspire samples in the [samples repo](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples) now demonstrate how non-project resources can be configured to use and trust the ASP.NET Core HTTPS development certificate so that they can host HTTPS endpoints that are trusted by the host browser (and other host resources) and trust the HTTPS endpoints of other resources that they connect to.

- [AspireWithNode](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/blob/0c27e4e3bac5f102db1002fd2e0e1ba894e1009a/samples/AspireWithNode/AspireWithNode.AppHost/Program.cs#L21-L24): Configures the front-end Node.js app to host HTTPS endpoints using the dev cert and trust connections to the back-end ASP.NET Core API project which is also using the dev cert.
- [Metrics](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/blob/0c27e4e3bac5f102db1002fd2e0e1ba894e1009a/samples/Metrics/MetricsApp.AppHost/OpenTelemetryCollector/OpenTelemetryCollectorResourceBuilderExtensions.cs#L30-L43): Configures the OpenTelemetry Collector container resource to host its endpoint using HTTPS via the dev cert and trust connections to downstream collectors (like the Aspire dashboard) that also use the dev cert.
- [Keycloak](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/blob/e20ba38263dbcc23a69899b4f797c0bf25895e40/samples/Keycloak/Keycloak.AppHost/KeycloakExtensions.cs#L23): Configures the Keycloak container resource to host its endpoints using HTTPS via the dev cert and trust connections to client apps including project resources that are using the dev cert.

All of these samples utilize a common helper [`DevCertHostingExtensions.cs`](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/blob/0c27e4e3bac5f102db1002fd2e0e1ba894e1009a/samples/Shared/DevCertHostingExtensions.cs).

We should consider adding this base helper capability natively to `Aspire.Hosting` and then updating the various hosting integrations to utilize it along with whatever custom logic is required for that specific integration to add a resource-specific `RunWithHttpsDevCertificate` overload that does what's required to configure the integration to correctly use the certificate.

Related issues:
- #5453
- #4132
title: Add support for configuring non-project resources to trust and/or use the ASP.NET Core HTTPS development certificate

author: fabrice-bauer
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Hello,

I am trying to use Aspire using 4 existing solutions. Each of these solutions contain between 10+ and 60+ projects.

I managed to create an Aspire host project referencing the 4 "main" projects of each solution and this works very well.
However when using the Aspire solution not all projects are there and therefore it is not possible to easily navigate code or rebuild everything.
I could manually add all existing projects into the Aspire solution but with the high number of projects this would be quite long plus it would require maintenance when we add new projects in the existing 4 solutions.


### Describe the solution you'd like

I am not fully sure if this should be managed by Aspire or Visual Studio but in this scenario being able to reference solutions from a solution could greatly help.

Thanks very much.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: FAYSALAHAMMAD2004
nodes.body: Hi there

nodes.author: joperezr
nodes.body:
Hello @fabrice-bauer, thanks for your submission. Out of curiosity, is there a reason why you can't just have everything in a single solution? What people do in similar situations, is to have a single `.sln` file that has all of the projects, and then have multiple solution filter files `.slnf` which can enable people that just want to open a subset of projects to be able to do so. You can find more information on solution filters [here](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/filtered-solutions?view=vs-2022), but the TL;DR is that they are very small files that just point to a solution, and apply some filters to it so that when you open that file (The .slnf file) with Visual Studio, it looks like if it were a different solution as it only has a subset of projects.

Doing this would allow you to continue working on a subset of projects when needed, but also allow you to fully orchestrate the projects with Aspire when you need to run everything, rebuild and debug.

nodes.author: fabrice-bauer
nodes.body:
Hello @joperezr, in fact I forgot to mention an important aspect which is that each solution and corresponding set of projects are in 4 separate repos.
But thinking about it again, this is probably not an Aspire related improvement but rather a Visual Studio one. 
I will also have a look at the new slnx format which might make it much easier to "replicate" the existing solutions content into the new one.
Thanks very much.

nodes.author: Mrxx99
nodes.body: @fabrice-bauer have you seen https://github.com/Dutchskull/Aspire.PolyRepo ?

nodes.author: fabrice-bauer
nodes.body:
Thanks @Mrxx99 I had not seen it, it can be very interesting, too, but it addresses the multi repo part. 
For the solution with all projects of all existing solutions to be able to rebuild and debug the whole distributed app from the single Aspire Host, it seems the new slnx format makes it much easier to maintain a new dedicated solution, so I will try it.

title: Add multi solutions support

author: christophe-mommer
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

I'm using Aspire to orchestrate my webapp and my database. I'm also using this database as part of several other projects, like test project.
Here's my setup:

```
var password = builder.AddParameter("sqlpassword", secret: true);
var sqlServer = builder
    .AddSqlServer(ConfigurationConstants.SqlServerConnectionName, password, 1433)
    .WithLifetime(ContainerLifetime.Persistent)
    .WithDataVolume(name: ConfigurationConstants.SqlServerDataVolumeName, isReadOnly: false)
    .WithContainerName("sql-server");

var sqlDatabase = sqlServer.AddDatabase(ConfigurationConstants.SqlDatabaseConnectionName);

webFrontEnd
    .WithReference(sqlDatabase)
    .WaitFor(sqlDatabase);
```

The thing is: when my Aspire app si running, I can access the database on port 1433 from other applications, even SSMS. However, when I shutdown my Aspire project, this database is no more accessible, even though it's marked as persistent. The container is still there, but the random port is the only one that allows me to acces the database, not the 1433 that I've specified.

Have I missed something in my configuration?

### Expected Behavior

_No response_

_No response_

### .NET Version info

.NET 9, Aspire 9

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body: @lupusbytes quick fyi - when using `ContainerLifetime.Persistent` it does stay running when Aspire shuts down - you can tell because in Docker Desktop it still shows it as "running", so yeah this is a bug 😁

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
My guess here is that `AddSqlServer()` () is using proxied endpoint for a persistent container, and once the app host stops, the proxy is gone, and the port specified is no longer valid. As a rule, it probably does not make sense to use proxied endpoints for persistent containers. 

So If that is correct, it is not a feature, but just a bug in the app model.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: Actually, the feature that we might be missing is "change the type of the endpoint depending on whether the container is persistent"

nodes.author: garrettlondon1
nodes.body: Can confirm as well, not able to connect to local sql server database running in docker container via Azure Data Studio without aspire running.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
> Actually, the feature that we might be missing is "change the type of the endpoint depending on whether the container is persistent"

We should just do this automatically right?

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
> > Actually, the feature that we might be missing is "change the type of the endpoint depending on whether the container is persistent"
> 
> We should just do this automatically right?

@danegsta is working on making non-proxied endpoints the default for persistent containers.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
We just merged https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/7232 which adds a new `.WithEndpointProxySupport` experimental API for container resources. Specifying `.WithEndpointProxySupport(false)` will disable proxying on all endpoints for a given resource. It's highly recommended to set explicit host ports for your container resources to avoid potential port conflicts as the default behavior for un-proxied container endpoints is to expose the endpoint using the internal port for the container.

We made the new API experimental and opt-in because there's additional larger work that will need to happen to unblock enabling the behavior by default, but we wanted to still provide a straightforward workaround in the short term. You can try out the API in nightly builds or the upcoming 9.1 release.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: Moving to Backlog--the workaround described above is what we intended to do in 9.1 timeframe. Additional work will come later.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: This issue intersects app model and the orchestrator

nodes.author: kieronlanning
nodes.body:
The `.WithEndpointProxySupport(false)` extension in 9.1 is working for me, thanks all.

Successfully and reliably connecting via SMSS and vscode on `127.0.0.1,{specific-port}`.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: Bringing back up in 9.2 to finish the work here so we can make this API non-experimental.

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: This involves quite a few large changes ,  we agreed to move this to 10.0 so moving to backlog until a milestone opens

nodes.author: jonataspc
nodes.body:
Just to add, if I enable `.WithEndpointProxySupport(false)` on an ASPNET CORE 9 web app I face a huge latency when using minimal APIs and Mediatr (12.5.0). Requests take ~2 seconds aftert `IMediator.Send()`. 
After removing `.WithEndpointProxySupport(false)` they take 10ms. 
I am still investigating that might be causing it, and what's the correlation between `.WithEndpointProxySupport(false)` and Mediatr.

nodes.author: HummingMind
nodes.body:
This also worked for me:

```
#pragma warning disable ASPIREPROXYENDPOINTS001
        var sqlServer = builder.AddSqlServer("sql")
            .WithLifetime(ContainerLifetime.Persistent)
            .WithEndpointProxySupport(false)
            .WithHostPort(5000);
#pragma warning restore ASPIREPROXYENDPOINTS001
```

Waiting for the real fix in v10 👍🏻

title: Sql Server container port is not accessible after Aspire is shutdown

author: davidfowl
body: There are a set of issues that we need to address wrt ContainerLifetime.Persistent, this is a tracking issue to roll up those other issues.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: cc @dbreshears @danegsta

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: As a first step we will log an issue in DCP for better diagnostic information as to why the persistent container is being re-created.

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: Additional logging was added to DCP and merged to Aspire repo

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
As a workaround for users who want to be able to access persistent containers on a consistent port whether the App Host is running or not, we merged #7232, which adds a new `WithEndpointProxySupport` experimental API that can be used to opt into running all endpoints for a container without a proxy (`.WithEndpointProxySupport(false)`). 

We made the new API experimental and opt-in because there's additional larger work that will need to happen before we can make running proxy-less endpoints the default, but we wanted to still provide a straightforward workaround in the short term. You can try out the API in nightly builds or the upcoming 9.1 release.

title: ContainerLifetime.Persistent roll issue roll up

nodes.author: Bellarmine-Head
nodes.body:
Server project; Properties | launchSettings.json

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/99dd44d4-87ba-427b-8e6a-2404f72219f5)

> My question is, how can I determine what URL will be (or has been) assigned by Visual Studio, please?

Since it's random, you can't determine what it *will* be, before creating the solution.

In addition to looking in the Server project's launch settings file, how about just loading the solution into VS, hitting F5 and seeing what the URL is in the browser?

nodes.author: BenjaminCharlton
nodes.body:
Good morning! And thanks for your interest, @Bellarmine-Head!

You might need to help me understand your second suggestion:

> how about just loading the solution into VS, hitting F5 and seeing what the URL is in the browser?

If I see what the URL is in the browser, it will be too late to add the address as a client of the Web API. Besides, it will  be different next time the app starts up. Maybe I didn't understand what you meant.

The first suggestion has got me thinking though:

> ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/05fd8d58-40be-4584-b6a2-91f7d06c30b4)

Your screenshot is the launchsettings.json is from a Blazor Server Project. If I could get the client to be run at the same URL as specified here, that would get me  unstuck, but my WebAssembly client is being served at a different localhost port every time I boot up the app, no matter what I put in launchsettings.json. In another app, I see this working. Maybe that's the root cause of my problem.

I've been doing a bit more research into this today and I'm convinced it's something to do with Aspire. The client and server of a hosted blazor web app share the same localhost address. But if you add them to an Aspire project, the server app's address (taken from launchsettings.json) is no longer the same as the client's (which is randomly generated).

nodes.author: Bellarmine-Head
nodes.body:
> Besides, it will be different next time the app starts up

No, it won't - or shouldn't be.  The port number is randomly chosen by the New Project template... which is only run once.


> Your screenshot is the launchsettings.json is from a Blazor Server Project.

My screenshot is from the `Server` project of a Blazor WebAssembly solution generated in 2020 (and modified manually in early 2024 to suit .NET 8), which has `Client`, `Server` and `Shared` projects, and no server-side rendering.  Now, I grant you it's not easy to generate such a solution these days, what with the .NET 8's and 9's appalling new-project template.

The current new-project template won't give you a `Shared` project, won't properly identify the `Server` project as such (hint: it's the project that isn't the `Client` project), and won't show you how to get data to the client from the server.  See [here](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/55307) for the sad and sorry details.


> but my WebAssembly client is being served at a different localhost port every time I boot up the app

Weird!


>  Maybe that's the root cause of my problem.

It is.


> and I'm convinced it's something to do with Aspire

uh-oh


>  But if you add them to an Aspire project, the server app's address (taken from launchsettings.json) is no longer the same as the client's (which is randomly generated).

Sounds nuts.  I've never used Aspire, and hopefully never will.  For all my Blazor WebAssembly web apps, the localhost port is:-

* set at the time of generating the new project (or more accurately: new solution)
* doesn't change (although you can edit launchSettings if you want to change it)
* used by both the `Server` and `Client` projects (i.e. used by the website as a whole)

nodes.author: BenjaminCharlton
nodes.body:
Yep, it's something to do with Aspire for sure. (Incidentally, I'm rather enjoying playing with Aspire, but it isn't Blazor-friendly yet, it would seem). I'm sure because:

1. If I create a new Blazor Web App with a Server and Client project, and leave the Server app as the startup project, it works fine (that is, it will be launched at the localhost port specified in `launchsettings.json`).
2. If I then right-click on the server project and go to _Add_ > _.NET Aspire Orchestrator Support_, I get an `AppHost` project now set as the startup project. Run that, and the Aspire dashboard shows the Blazor server project running at the correct localhost address from its `launchsettings.json`. However, the browser window that opens shows the app running on a random port that changes every time the project starts up.

That's the root cause.
By the way, I found your links very interesting and agree strongly with you and bossman Steve Sanderson on that!

title: Aspire launches the client of a hosted Blazor WebAssembly app on a different random port every time the AppHost is launched

author: karolz-ms
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

In .NET 9.1 `dotnet run` gains two new launch options that would be useful for launching projects in the context of an Aspire app:

1. `-e` causes an environment variable to be applied to the application being launched, but NOT to the targets participating in the application build (unlike the old `env:` option).

2. `--no-launch-profile-arguments` allows to ignore invocation arguments in launch profiles

See https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/45844 for an example how these options are used in the context of `dotnet watch`

### Describe the solution you'd like

Ideally these options would be used to launch projects when Aspire app host is launched from command line via `dotnet run`. The problem is they are only available in .NET 9.1 and newer. So either Aspire app host needs to somehow learn what `dotnet` CLI version is available and change the launch options used accordingly, or start using these new launch options only after .NET 9.1 or later becomes a required dependency for Aspire.

### Additional context

@DamianEdwards FYI

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
karolz-ms
nodes.body: Yes, sorry, 9.0.200 series

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Ideally we'd do feature detection instead of version detection, but I don't think we can get the output of `dotnet run --help` in a stable structured format today, right @baronfel?

nodes.author: danmoseley
nodes.body:
>  feature detection instead of version detection

version detection is fine if features are monotonically added?

I was going to suggest return code, but I guess `dotnet` ignores unknown switches

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: This isn't happenning in 9.1

nodes.author: baronfel
nodes.body:
> Ideally we'd do feature detection instead of version detection, but I don't think we can get the output of `dotnet run --help` in a stable structured format today, right [@baronfel](https://github.com/baronfel)?

yeah, that's right. In the extreme this is 'just' a json dump of the CLI grammar for a Command, which would be a really interesting thing. You want to check a structure and see if it contains a flag or capability?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
> You want to check a structure and see if it contains a flag or capability?

Yeah, ideally we'd check if the feature we want to invoke is present, rather than just version check.

title: Use new 'dotnet run' 9.1 options for launching projects

author: davidfowl
body:
This is a bigger problem around endpoints and the ability to query for an endpoint in different network context. An endpoint might be tied to a container network, or the host network or an external proxy that points to your internal facing port. There are scenarios with tools like devtunnels, ngrok, devContainer, codespaces, YARP etc.

A good sniff test is using keycloak when there's a proxy. The redirect URL needs to be the right url in a given context and we have no way of resolving the url based on the context. If I'm running in a codespace the redirect url is different and I shouldn't have to change the code in different contexts.

Found this while running the keycloak sample in codespaces.

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body: I've also just hit this with configuring CORS - I needed to configure a resource running on the host to connect to an http server in a container.  Aspire unhelpfully converted my endpoint url to `http://host.docker.internal:1234`, but I needed it kept as `localhost` for CORS.

nodes.author: joetossell
nodes.body:
To add to this I have an issue where I am running a utility in a docker container orchestrated by aspire. The utility accepts a URI to a file in storage to do some processing. We have an app service that is generating a SAS url for a file stored in azurite. We then need to pass the uri to the utility. Unfortunately the SAS uri then needs to work for the container network.

It would be very useful to get an endpoint reference for the container network to perform this substitution in the app service.

title: Need a way to get as for endpoints in a specific context

author: sebastienros
body:
## Problem

Persistent lifetime relies on checking the state of the resources to detect if it can reuse an existing instance or start a fresh one. This state uses things like ENVs, volume mounts, parameters, ... Any changed value between two runs will require a restart.

Some resources are coded in a way that make it impossible to be persistent. Here are some things that I found while working on [Azure Service Bus resource](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/7071), but this is definitely not the whole list of potential issues:
- The emulator requires a sql resource. The lifetime state was not forwarded to this container and it would then be re-created. Sub-resources should be applied the same lifetime.
- A random password was generated every time for the sub-resource, invalidating the previous hash. The solution was to store the password in user secrets and reuse it if it exists.
- A file mount needed to be created to host the custom configuration for the emulator. A new file in a random temporary folder was created, invalidating the hash. The solution was to store the path to this resource.

[Suggest other constraints]

## Suggestions

These problems will be common to most resources. Here are some proposals that should help mitigate state changes between restarts.

### Temporary files

Temporary file names should be deterministically found. This means not using random folders or file names. And the file name should be based on a hash of the content such that we get a new file when its content changes. (and reuse the same file if the content is the same).

Examples:
- `%TEMP%/AzureServiceBus-{resourceName}-{contentHash}.Config.Json`
- `%TEMP%/AzureServiceBus-{resourceName}.Config.Json/{contentHash}`

### Storing files in the app's `/bin` directory

Storing files in the temp folder without context could lead to conflicts between applications (same resource types and names). These files can't be cleaned though. Using the `/bin` folder of each app would mean they have the same lifetime as the app. Would be cleaned using `git clean` too.

### Use the Secret Store folder

Right now the easiest way to store data for an application across runs is to use the Secret Store. Generated Password Parameters are already using it. It requires the creation of a unique identifier in the csproj. And option could be to use it for other things than app secrets.

`%AppData%/Microsoft/UserSecrets`

`./secrets.json`

### Using the user profile (Aspire Store)

`%AppData%/Aspire/[AssemblyIdentifier/Hash]/store.json`

Provide the same functionality as the user Secrets Store but isolated from it: 
- Not mixing secrets with data that just require cross-runs storage
- Not requiring a guid in the csproj (could be an assembly attribute of a hash of the assembly location).

### Potential useful methods

On top of the functionalities provided by the existing [`SecretsStore.cs`](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/main/src/Shared/SecretsStore.cs) these could be useful:
```
string GetAspireStoreFolder();
string GetOrCreateFileWithContent(string path, byte[] contentHash);
```

nodes.author: sebastienros
nodes.body: /cc @karolz-ms @ReubenBond @davidfowl @captainsafia @DamianEdwards @JamesNK @eerhardt

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body: I like the `Using the user profile (Aspire Store)` approach. My only reservation is that we could be orphaning these files if you F5 an Aspire project once, then delete the project and never run it again.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
So far I've been using a directory in the temp directory named for the app host hash to store this kind of detail, e.g. https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/blob/f3cb5c4baddd75ab97b8d8a912ff20026c710700/samples/Shared/DevCertHostingExtensions.cs#L80

This means we're getting a stable, unique location for every instance of an app host project based on the same logic used internally to identify app host instances (which takes into consideration project name and path), and because it's under the temp path we don't need to be concerned with orphans.

nodes.author: sebastienros
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards Thank you. Then a utility class could reuse your logic. And also ensure we are using the correct file permissions for temporary files on linux: I think the code you are pointing to doesn't do it correctly, it could use `GetTempFileName()` and move the file to the one you want, like SecretsStore.cs does. By using a common aspire folder with the correct permission we wouldn't even have to care about it every time.

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
Note that `/tmp` is shared with all users on a Linux machine. Using it is a bit of a security concern that I've seen elsewhere.

https://systemd.io/TEMPORARY_DIRECTORIES/

> Note that /tmp/ and /var/tmp/ each define a common namespace shared by all local software. This means guessable file or directory names below either directory directly translate into a 🚨 Denial-of-Service (DoS) 🚨 vulnerability or worse: if some software creates a file or directory /tmp/foo then any other software that wants to create the same file or directory /tmp/foo either will fail (as the file already exists) or might be tricked into using untrusted files. Hence: do not use guessable names in /tmp/ or /var/tmp/

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
> Note that /tmp is shared with all users on a Linux machine. Using it is a bit of a security concern that I've seen elsewhere.

Woah, OK. Is that documented WRT to `Path.GetTempPath()`?

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
> Woah, OK. Is that documented WRT to `Path.GetTempPath()`?

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.io.path.gettemppath?view=net-9.0&tabs=linux just says 

> If the TMPDIR environment variable has been set, this method returns the value specified by that environment variable.
>
> Otherwise, this method returns /tmp/.

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/19389 and https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2018/11/07/dotnet-special-folder-api-linux also has some commentary.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
We do have a proposed feature for DCP where one could get the content of a file on the host automatically copied into the newly created container at startup https://github.com/microsoft/usvc/issues/197 . We could even go as far as to, for existing persistent containers that otherwise meets reuse criteria, comparing the (source) file with data with its copy inside the container and rewrite the file in the container if they are different ((using the standard copy-then-rename trick for consistent file view). That will only work if the container is watching for file changes, so it might be an opt-in enhancement. That would free the app host from managing temporary files, dealing with intricacies of bind/volume mounts etc.

For secrets .NET secret store is a good default to be the source of the data. For non-secret data something simple like `.gitignored` folder in the app workspace could do.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
karolz-ms
nodes.body: Storing non-secret, dev-time information outside of the app source folder ("workspace") has the drawback that it introduces yet another folder (beyond user secrets folder) that needs to be managed/cleaned up when you are done working on some application.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
> Storing non-secret, dev-time information outside of the app source folder ("workspace") has the drawback that it introduces yet another folder (beyond user secrets folder) that needs to be managed/cleaned up when you are done working on some application.

Yeah I agree it's a shame but hardly unheard of. If we do the work to make sure these files are tracked by the build and thus cleaned up properly by `dotnet build` I'm more than happy to put them in `/obj` or `/bin` (we should figure out which is more idiomatic).

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
> Yeah I agree it's a shame but hardly unheard of. If we do the work to make sure these files are tracked by the build and thus cleaned up properly by `dotnet build` I'm more than happy to put them in `/obj` or `/bin` (we should figure out which is more idiomatic).

I understand this is a matter of preference and style but I would personally prefer a different trade-off. Even if `dotnet clean` did not clean some of the dev-time assets (but `git clean` did), I would say it is a much more acceptable niusance compared to `rm -rf ~/code/myAppFolder` still leaving some stuff related to "myApp" p on the file system.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
eerhardt
nodes.body: I think @karolz-ms's idea of a new `.gitignore`'d folder is another option we should at least consider. We could make a `.aspire` folder next to the AppHost .csproj, and the files get written to there. The downsides to this is yet another folder to add to all the `.gitignore` files of repos that have Aspire apps. But maybe that is acceptable? There might not even be a problem if people check these generated files into source control if the file name and contents are deterministic given the same AppHost code.

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
I think of the existing options, a new folder in the User Profile and a new `.gitignore` folder are the front runners. Each have downsides.

Trying to be "forward thinking" if we are writing a lot of files here (a bunch of integrations do) and if the files get larger, it feels like putting them in a place that is easily cleaned up might be the best option.

nodes.author: sebastienros
nodes.body: I think this is a decision we can reconsider if we change our mind after testing or if something better comes. This is persistent data but also deleting the folder would not be critical, just a one-time annoyance. Meaning let's roll a dice or go with the simpler/straightforward option.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Why not put them in `/obj` so that you don't have yet another directory to think about and especially have to add to .gitignore?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: FWIW I went with `/obj` in my [samples PR just now](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/pull/667)

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
I'm a little hesitant about adding another hard coded path to the AppHost assembly metadata, but we are already down that path with AppHostProjectPath and the Dcp and Dashboard exe paths. One way we can mitigate that concern is allowing for configuration (i.e. environment variables) to override it. That way you can build an AppHost on one machine and run it on another (like we do in our tests).

Maybe the `/obj` route has the least downsides. And as @sebastienros says, we can always change our mind later, if we find a better place or run into issues with this route.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: I agree that direction of embedding more stuff into the assembly (paths), feels like the opposite direction of where we want to go. Maybe time to introduce a side file?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
>Maybe time to introduce a side file?

As in, `.aspire` in the project directory, that gets copied to bin (so it's easy to find next to the running assembly)? That would require additions to `.gitignore` right, as you don't want that checked in?

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
The "side file" would get generated at build time next to the AppHost.dll in the `bin` directory. Similar to the `runtimeconfig.json` file in .NET Core. The data that is going into AssemblyMetadataAttributes now would be written there instead. See https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/2036.

I think if we were to do this over again, that's probably the route we should go. But I'm not sure we need it right now with this. I think we could get by using the existing pattern of AssemblyMetadata and a configuration/environment variable to override would work.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Sometimes you need a forcing function 😄

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
So, more custom MSBuild that we need to maintain 😐 

I certainly like the idea of env var overrides for the values derived from those currently stamped into the assembly, i.e. you could override the path to the generated config file for pgAdmin, but if it's not set the path is derived from the project-relevant paths in the assembly/side-file.

Least friction for now would seem to be what @eerhardt said and keep doing what we're doing and add config/environment variable overrides for relevant things. We could decide to tackle moving to a side file in 10.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: What would make us do that work?

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body: I'm not sure we _need_ to do the side file anymore now that we can set environment variables (via config) to override these paths.

nodes.author: L968
nodes.body:
> A random password was generated every time for the sub-resource, invalidating the previous hash. The solution was to store the password in user secrets and reuse it if it exists.

I came up with using a fixed username/password for the container, using the builder.AddParameter() method. Probably not the best workaround but it works.
But I think the biggest issue is that I had to figure out this error on my own (the fact that the connection was not being established successfully). I struggled a little bit and I can see how this could affect others as well.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
davidfowl
nodes.body: @sebastienros is this done?

title: Suggestions for better persistent containers implementation

author: davidfowl
body:
Consider exposing [these methods](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/9aab40b5601be2d7c9e07f6ca3bb409c97de7e46/tests/Aspire.Hosting.Tests/Utils/LoggerNotificationExtensions.cs#L13) in a first class way for testing and potentially to resources. As a low level health check, a container without inbound network connectivity might wait for a particular log to be considered healthy.

cc @ReubenBond @DamianEdwards

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Yep nice idea. I've seen customers trying to do this themselves already and of course we have [these related methods](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/blob/2bc9d5d26f0d7d2e0519d5a3d24ba5d96ab2feed/tests/SamplesIntegrationTests/Infrastructure/DistributedApplicationExtensions.cs#L199) in the samples repo.

title: Consider exposing WaitForText* methods

author: ReubenBond
body:
## Background and Motivation

See: https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/7363#discussion_r1938335951

Developers, particularly during testing, occasionally need to modify configuration which is currently only accessible through IConfiguration. Eg, to configure port randomization during testing, dashboard disablement, resource suffixes, etc.

Here are some examples:
- `DcpPublisher:ContainerRuntimeInitializationTimeout`
- `DcpPublisher:RandomizePorts`
- `DcpPublisher:DeleteResourcesOnShutdown`
- `DcpPublisher:ResourceNameSuffix`
- `ASPNETCORE_URLS` (for the AppHost dashboard URL)
- `DOTNET_DASHBOARD_OTLP_ENDPOINT_URL`

## Proposed API

Expose these properties via `DistributedApplicationOptions`, which is passed in to `DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(DistributedApplicationOptions)` and which is available via the various testing builder creation API overloads on 'DistributedApplicationTestingBuilder`.

## Usage Examples

<!--
Please provide code examples that highlight how the proposed API additions are meant to be consumed.
This will help suggest whether the API has the right shape to be functional, performant and useable.
You can use code blocks like this:
```csharp
// some lines of code here
```
-->

## Alternative Designs

<!--
Were there other options you considered, such as alternative API shapes?
How does this compare to analogous APIs in other ecosystems and libraries?
-->

## Risks

<!--
Please mention any risks that to your knowledge the API proposal might entail, such as breaking changes, performance regressions, etc.
-->

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: We should also take this opportunity to clean up the naming of the configuration keys.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @mitchdenny we should clean this up. @DamianEdwards did a round of this cleaning up the env variables (ASPIRE_*). We should do the same with these settings.

title: [Proposal] Add APIs to configure DCP options

author: arielmoraes
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

When using a Project Resource and for any reason it is terminated because of an exception while in debug, in other words, exit code not 0, the dashboard does not keep track of this and marks it as Finished without errors. A consequence is that if another resource is set to `WaitForCompletion` it'll start as if the referenced project was gracefully finished.

App1 is finished with an exception:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d3a4c03a-4149-490c-b3e0-0a19a159cf41)

App2 is started even if the completion exited with error:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5ae963ad-54f7-4ac9-bdf5-e091e31ad7e8)

The AppHost is very simple:
```csharp
var app1 = builder.AddProject<Projects.ConsoleApp1>("app1");

builder.AddProject<Projects.ConsoleApp2>("app2")
    .WithExternalHttpEndpoints()
    .WaitForCompletion(app1);
```

### Expected Behavior

The DCP should keep track of the debug exit code instead of marking the resource as Finished without errors.

### Steps To Reproduce

Repro project: https://github.com/arielmoraes/AspireFinishedStateError

I've just created the full Aspire template with two simple console app.

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

.NET SDK:
 Version:           9.0.102
 Commit:            cb83cd4923
 Workload version:  9.0.100-manifests.4a54b1a6
 MSBuild version:   17.12.18+ed8c6aec5

Ambiente de runtime:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.26100
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\9.0.102\

Cargas de trabalho do .NET instaladas:
 [aspire]
   Origem da Instalação: VS 17.12.35707.178
   Versão do Manifesto:    8.2.2/8.0.100
   Caminho do Manifesto:       C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk-manifests\8.0.100\microsoft.net.sdk.aspire\8.2.2\WorkloadManifest.json
   Tipo de Instalação:              Msi


### Anything else?

Using Visual Studio with Aspire 9.0.0 and ASP.NET Core 9

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
I'm not sure we are consistent WRT how run and exit works. We have both Exited and Finished states depending on what is running the application (IDE vs dotnet run).

We should aim to clean this up and be consistent. 

1. Finished vs Exited, do we need both?
2. ExitCode should be tracked in all cases

@karolz-ms @JakeRadMSFT @tmat

nodes.author: arielmoraes
nodes.body:
I was reading a bit further and I found out that VS reports an unhandled exception as exit code 0 when debugging. The source is in this comment from 5 years ago https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/35599#issuecomment-621954472. 

I have no clue what the quirk they refer to is, but returning an exit code different than 0 from main makes Aspire work as intended.

Don't know if there is something Aspire can do about that, as it's up to the application to choose which exit code to return. If the application handles using the unhandled exception event it has a chance to also set the exit code.

So, the only problem is not handling an exception while debugging in VS.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
Agree with @davidfowl we should report the state of an Executable as `Exited` when the program ends, regardless whether it is run from IDE or command line.

Edit: opened https://github.com/microsoft/usvc/issues/202 to fix

nodes.author: arielmoraes
davidfowl
nodes.body: @arielmoraes we're not going to fix that, but, we'll unify the state.

nodes.author: sibbl
nodes.body:
Unfortunately the `AppDomain.CurrentDomain.UnhandledException` workaround doesn't make a difference over here.

Throwing exceptions let the application show up as "Failed" - returning an exit code is simply ignored and it always shows up with exit code 0 in Aspire.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: @sibbl do you have an app that demonstrates the issue that you'd be willing to share?

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
@sgentry do you have any kind of proxy running for localhost traffic? We've seen certificate issues in the past for users who have local traffic being proxied (in some cases via an accidental proxy config and in others all IPv6 traffic was being proxied, but IPv4 worked as expected).

The orchestrator layer doesn't currently support self-signed certificates, but that's something we could consider in the future if there's enough interest.

nodes.author: sgentry
nodes.body:
No, I don't have any local proxy setup that I'm aware of. Up until the middle of last year we did have to use our corporate proxy, which caused various issues. As far as I can tell, I've cleared out all previous configuration I had set for corp proxy. I'll keep poking around and see if I can get another developer to test it out on their machine.

In regards to providing my own cert, I was thinking about generating new certs from a trusted Vault CA we use in our development environment.

nodes.author: sgentry
