nodes.author: JFelton
nodes.body:
I've run into this with our company proxy server during evaluation to promote for use by our development staff.

I'm able to get aspire to start correctly when removing the Windows Environment Variables for both HTTP_PROXY & HTTPS_PROXY.  The NO_PROXY does not have to be removed.  Of course closing and reopening visual studio.

I'm looking for a way to promote the use of .Net Aspire within our company, yet need an acceptable answer for this proxy interference.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: @JFelton the general recommendation for scenarios like this would be to exclude local machine traffic from proxies. Unless your proxy is running on the individual developer machines (which generally defeats the purpose of a shared corporate proxy), it’s not going to be able to resolve localhost traffic back to your machine. Adding localhost/127.0.0.1 to the NO_PROXY environment variable got Aspire is more of a workaround for an improperly configured proxy routing setup that isn’t already excluding localhost traffic.

nodes.author: sgentry
nodes.body:
In my case I no longer use the corporate proxy and have removed the HTTP_PROXY env variables.

I was troubleshooting this with our desktop support today and there are not any policies enabled that would interfere with certs that they're aware of. Is there something specific we should look at?

I can see that `kubeconfig` is created under `Users\AppData\Local\Temp\Aspire...`. Is the `certificate-authority-data` generated every time you run the app? Is this the CA that needs to be trusted on my machine?

If you have any ideas on how I could troubleshoot this, it would be much appreciated.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: @sgentry there shouldn't be any need to explicitly trust the CA certificate as the C# KubernetesClient library [automatically validates](https://github.com/kubernetes-client/csharp/blob/master/src/KubernetesClient/Kubernetes.ConfigInit.cs#L188) against the CA cert in the kubeconfig. The two primary scenarios that could cause that check in the KubernetesClient library to fail would be a mismatch between the NotBefore/NotAfter settings for the certificate and the current system clock or a mismatch between the subject name of the certificate and the address it was actually requested for (the certificate has its subject name set to the loopback address that the orchestration layer is running on).

nodes.author: bradengc-github
nodes.body: I'm chiming in as another person that is also having this issue. I've been trying to troubleshoot it for a couple days now without any luck. The only way I was able to get it to briefly work was to set a breakpoint in the Aspire code in the spot before the error was thrown, add `insecure-skip-tls-verify: true` to the kubeconfig and then resume. Is there a way to disable the SSL validation via environment variable?

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
@bradengc-github sorry, there is no way to disable the SSL validation when connecting to DCP.

So far, when we see these authentication errors reported by `DcpExecutor`, they have been one of the following (or a combination of these):

1. There is some sort of system proxy that tries to intercept the connection attempt between Aspire app host and DCP.
2. As above, but it is the antivirus software on the machine that tries to intercept the connection attempt.
3. It is a dual-stack machine (IPv4 and IPv6) and IPv6 is configured differently than IPv4, or the unique IPv6 loopback address (`[::1]`) does not work for some reason. As a workaround one can try telling Aspire app host to prefer IPv4 by setting an environment variable (the example is using PowerShell syntax):

```shell
$env:DCP_IP_VERSION_PREFERENCE="IPv4"; dotnet run --project <path to AppHost project file>
``` 

Let us know please if this was helpful in any way.

nodes.author: bradengc-github
nodes.body:
I appreciate the reply.

> 1. There is some sort of system proxy that tries to intercept the connection attempt between Aspire app host and DCP.

There is a proxy that man-in-the-middles HTTPS requests, but I had our IT folks disable it temporarily to see if that was the problem and I still got the same error.

> 2. As above, but it is the antivirus software on the machine that tries to intercept the connection attempt.

This could theoretically be happening, but I'm not sure about this one. I had a colleague try this on their (allegedly identically imaged) machine and it worked for them.

> 3. It is a dual-stack machine (IPv4 and IPv6) and IPv6 is configured differently than IPv4, or the unique IPv6 loopback address (`[::1]`) does not work for some reason. As a workaround one can try telling Aspire app host to prefer IPv4 by setting an environment variable (the example is using PowerShell syntax):

>> $env:DCP_IP_VERSION_PREFERENCE="IPv4"; dotnet run --project <path to AppHost project file>

No dice here either, unfortunately - same error. I've been working around this by working with WSL + Remote Development in WSL, where it works. Unfortunately that means I can't use Visual Studio proper. Something is wonky in Windows-land, I just don't know how what or how to fix it.

nodes.author: bradengc-github

nodes.author: JakubTracz
nodes.body: Same problem here on WIndows 10. Tried adding env variables for NO_PROXY and preferred IP version - no luck.

nodes.author: detachmode
nodes.body: Me and my colleagues also have this issue. Also on a work machine with HTTP proxies. Only way to get it working is to unset the HTTP_PROXY env car and restart rider.

nodes.author: TylerReid
nodes.body:
I had this issue as well. We have a corporate mitm proxy with an internal CA, so it wouldn't have worked if localhost goes to the proxy anyway, but it extra didn't work and failed on the cert. In my case on mac this fixes it: `export no_proxy="$no_proxy,[::1]"` `export NO_PROXY=$no_proxy` (do both cases because [http proxy hates you](https://about.gitlab.com/blog/we-need-to-talk-no-proxy/) ) then just `dotnet run` from that terminal.

As with all env vars and proxy things, if that doesn't work for you make sure you are setting it in a global way for your OS and potentially restarting so that all processes get the new value, such as vs code, vs etc. Since processes inherit these things and you might accidentally not be testing the change.

Corporate http proxies are like playing on Hard Mode for essentially everything. I wish that Microsoft forced devs to use one, just so these things get documented more, but I bet the engineers would curse me for saying that 😆.

author: JamesNK
body:
Exceptions thrown in the app host are always printed to the debug console. Althrough the errors are handled, they add noise the debug console. For example, https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/7486

Common exceptions:
- k8s.Autorest throws `HttpOperationException` in many situations. For example, `GetAsync` for a resource that doesn't exist throws the error. I'm not sure what options there are to suppress them.
- `OperationCanceledException` is thrown from many canceled async operations. For example, canceling watching for resource notifications. `ConfigureAwaitOptions.NoThrow` could be used to stop them. Or gracefully completing channels when we no longer want to read from them instead of aborting read with a cancellation token.
title: Reduce exceptions thrown in Aspire.Hosting

author: afscrome
body:
## Background and Motivation

`ReferenceExpressionBuilder` is a really useful way of building up a longer reference expression when you may need to encode multiple distinct values into a single environment variable.

```cs
var expression = new ReferenceExpressionBuilder();
expression.AppendLiteral("user=admin;")
expression.Append($"host={endpoint.Property(EndpointProperty.Host)};")
expression.Append($"port={endpoint.Property(EndpointProperty.Port)};")
return expression.Build();
```

Whilst the API works, it would be a lot more convenient if the API could used in a fluent manner, simplifying the above to:

```cs
return new ReferenceExpressionBuilder();
   .AppendLiteral("user=admin;")
   .Append($"host={endpoint.Property(EndpointProperty.Host)};")
   .Append($"port={endpoint.Property(EndpointProperty.Port)};")
   .Build();
```

## Proposed API

```diff
namespace Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel;
public class ReferenceExpressionBuilder
{
-    public void Append([InterpolatedStringHandlerArgument("")] in ReferenceExpressionBuilderInterpolatedStringHandler handler)
+    public ReferenceExpressionBuilder Append([InterpolatedStringHandlerArgument("")] in ReferenceExpressionBuilderInterpolatedStringHandler handler)
-    public void AppendLiteral(string value)
+    public ReferenceExpressionBuilder AppendLiteral(string value)
-    public void AppendFormatted(string? value)
+    public ReferenceExpressionBuilder AppendFormatted(string? value)
-    public void AppendFormatted<T>(T valueProvider) where T : IValueProvider, IManifestExpressionProvider
+    public ReferenceExpressionBuilder AppendFormatted<T>(T valueProvider) where T : IValueProvider, IManifestExpressionProvider
}
```

This changes each `void` method into returning `ReferenceExpressionBuilder`.  Each method's implementation would remain the same as the old version but with the addition of `return this;` at the end of each method to support a fluent api.

## Usage Examples

```cs
return new ReferenceExpressionBuilder();
   .Append($"foo,")
   .Append($"bar")
   .Build();
```


## Alternative Designs

No alternative designs considered.  This new design mirrors `StringBuilder`'s fluent API.

## Risks

This is an API breaking change by changing the method return types from void to `ReferenceExpressionBuilder `
title: Make `ReferenceExpressionBuilder` Fluent

author: afscrome
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

I've had a few collegues needing to do things with `ReferenceExpression` which don't work because they unintentionally worked the ReferenceExpression into a regular interpolated string e.g.

```cs
kafka.WithEnvironment("KAFKA_ADVERTISED_LISTENERS",
         $"PLAINTEXT://localhost:29092," +
         $"PLAINTEXT_HOST://localhost:{kafka.GetEndpoint("primary").Property(EndpointProperty.Port)}")}," +
```

Which fails because the reference expression ultimately ends up being serialized as the literal string `Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ReferenceExpression` rather than the desired port 

### Describe the solution you'd like

It would be nice if we could do something to make these errors more obvious.  A few possibiliteis off the top of my head

1. Have `ReferenceExpression.ToString()` throw an error - it seems like you should only ever stringify a reference expression with `.GetValueAsync()` or `.ValueExpression`, and never `.ToString()`.  Would probaby require adding `[DebuggerDisplay("{ValueExpression}")]` to stop the debugger complaining

2. An analyser that detects when `ReferenceExpression` is used inside an interpolated string that isn't itself used in an interpolated expression, and produce a compiler warning.

First option is the easier implementation, but having `.ToString()` throw could feels sketchy - e.g. what if a `ReferenceExpression` ever ends up being passed to a logging framework.



### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
Another source of confusion - you'd think the two below ways of setting environment variables below would behave the same.
```cs
.WithEnvironment("Foo1", $"{blobsEndpoint.Property(EndpointProperty.Host)}")
.WithEnvironment(ctx => ctx.EnvironmentVariables["Foo2"] = $"{blobsEndpoint.Property(EndpointProperty.Host)}");
```

However the first one works correctly, whilst the second does not, so there's a bit of a pit of failure to fall into if you move a value into the callback version of `WithEnvironment`.

title: Protect against using `ReferenceExpression` in a regular interpoalted string

author: richardszalay
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

When debugging and a code change cannot be hot reloaded, it requires a rebuild/restart of the entire Aspire application, but it would be more productive to only rebuild/restart the impacted projects.

### Describe the solution you'd like

To start this off, I appreciate that this is no small ask (to put it mildly) and that it likely larger than the Aspire / ASP.NET teams (i.e. involving the VS team). However, I do feel like it would be a great feature if its achievable.

Let's say I have the following:

* AppHost
* ServiceDefaults
* Class library "A"
* Web project "B" (depends on "A" + ServiceDefaults)
* Web project "C" (depends on ServiceDefaults)

If I start-with-debugging and change something that cannot be hot reloaded in "C", theoretically the service could be stopped, rebuilt, and restarted without having to rebuild/restart the app host and all of the other projects.

Admittedly, dependencies make this even more complex (changes to "A" rebuilds/restarts "B" but not "C", changes to "ServiceDefaults" rebuilds/restarts all projects but not AppHost, etc) but the resulting developer experience improvements would be fantastic.

### Additional context

To avoid this being closed as a duplicate, I want to clarify how this issue differs from several existing ones:

#295 Involves the developer manually stopping/starting services. This issue is about Visual Studio working with Aspire to automate the stop/rebuild/start cycle of impacted projects _only_.

#923 Involves keeping specific resources running after shutdown, with a specific focus on containers and/or other "not my code" resources.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
There are 3 ways to accomplish this today for projects:
1. Use dotnet watch from the 9.0.200 sdk
2. Use hit reload in vs/vs code
3. Use ctrl+f5 in visualstudio. Rebuilding one project will restart it in place.


3 is personally my favorite as there are no limitations to the types of changes that can be made.

I don’t think this is enough to provide the best experience, we need some clean way of not tearing everything down if you rebuild the whole solution (which some people do), but we have some experiences coming online that are headed in this direction.

The problem with debugging is that a full rebuild is needed in many cases and that requires a detach and reattach. Simple changes like adding packages can’t be done in debug mode. I wonder if it’s worth investing in changes there or if it’s better to change people’s muscle memory.

nodes.author: richardszalay
nodes.body:
Thanks for the summary of current workarounds.

Is it theoretically possible to detach from just the impacted processes, terminate them, rebuild, run and attach without having to detach from _unimpacted_ projects?

Sorry if this is more of a vs-team question

author: 3GDXC
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

A number of public images fail in functionality when attemping to validate CA from behind a proxy; and require registration of the proxy CA to allow the images to work correctly under .NET ASPIRE and/or container service such as kubernetes.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Please consider adding functionality that allows for the injection of a CA certificate into a container; so that containers place/running behind a proxy (such as zscaler) can validate the certificate authority.

extension method for resource builder of T .AddCertificateAuthority("certificate.crt")

### Additional context

eg. ollama add model fails with error around unknown certificate authority

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Yep this is something we're looking to enable, and we already do it in some of the samples today.

nodes.author: 3GDXC
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards I'm looking at possibly creating a something like a **ContainerCommandExecutionResource** and **ContainerCommandExecutionClient** that could possibly assist with this by allowing aspire applicationhost to perform the required commands on the container and restarting the container where there is a need like installation of CA certificates when the host is using services like **zscaler**

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: @3GDXC that's interesting, as all the examples I've made work so far (Redis, Keycloak, otel-collector, etc.) have been on containers that include first-class support for injecting certificates via bind mounts and environment variables, but I understand that some (many/most?) containers won't have such support and rather require running a custom script or command to configure the container OS or app running the container to use the certificate. The way we've done that is to bind mount a custom entrypoint script and set it as the entrypoint for the container. It might end up that we need all these mechanisms be supported to fully support any container, but we intend to start out with focused on containers that already support setting environment variables to inject certificates.

nodes.author: los93sol
nodes.body: The way trust-manager deals with this is pretty good for most containers.  You basically build a bundle and it can automatically include the standard ca certs, slip in your self signed chains and certs and mount it over the certs directory so you don’t need to run scripts to update ca certs.  Works for a lot of scenarios.

nodes.author: 3GDXC

title: Feature: Injection of a certificate into container

author: davidfowl
body:
See https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/7826#issuecomment-2690165144

We should show connection string resources in the dashboard. These should be either in an "Active" or an "Error" state.

We'll go with "Active" as the new state. It'll be a terminal state 
https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/5faec12d5f9a91fea7a2b2b8a6780942df0b8831/src/Aspire.Hosting/ApplicationModel/CustomResourceSnapshot.cs#L401

We should make connection string resources Active. We should also support health checks on Active resources. Right now we only consider running https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/5faec12d5f9a91fea7a2b2b8a6780942df0b8831/src/Aspire.Hosting/Health/ResourceHealthCheckService.cs#L42.

Active should show up like running in the dashboard as well (with all of the same checks for health).

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards thoughts?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
This is timely as I just had to fix the tests in the sample repo to handle custom resources that never have a Running state. Some ideas:

- Active 
- Available
- Applied
- Ready

Whatever we choose should be added to the known terminal states too.

title: Introduce new state for resources without a lifetime outside of "Running"

author: 3GDXC
body:
## Background and Motivation
I would like to create a set of extensions that allow the developer to connect to a container shell and exec shell commands upon the first start of the container; to do this the information held in the DcpInstanceAnnotation would be used.

## Proposed API

please make the DcpInstancesAnnotation (currently internal) public

## Usage Examples
## Alternative Designs
## Risks

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
> I would like to create a set of extensions that allow the developer to connect to a container shell and exec shell commands upon the first start of the container; to do this the information held in the DcpInstanceAnnotation would be used.

How are you going to do this?

nodes.author: 3GDXC
nodes.body: The idea was around using the IDistributedApplicationBuilder.Eventing to subscribe to the ResourceReadyEvent; the event has the event.Resouce.Annontations holds the DcpInstanceAnnontation; a linq express would be applied to obtain the details and connect using a k8s client and passed to a developer function that can call the appropriate client commands

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: I'm not sure that is a good design. There's a feature in DCP that allows for running commands inside of containers that hasn't been exposed in a meaningful way as yet https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/6481

nodes.author: 3GDXC
nodes.body: @davidfowl didn't see the #6481 and was looking at the eventing subscription performing the initial commands; if there are plans to expose this type of feature that's great, however given someone still may require to read/evaluate/query over the event.Resource.Annontations it still maybe worth making the class public.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: I don't have a problem making it public if there are valid uses for it. I don't think we want to expose dcp internals in a way that would stop us from making changes in the future.

nodes.author: 3GDXC
nodes.body: @davidfowl understand that completely; if something similar to the extensions .TryGetContainerImage(out string? imageName) was applied for the resource collection then that would also make sense; possibly .TryGetContainerInstances(out IEnumerable<ContainerInstance> instances) and the DcpInstanceAnnontation wouldn't need exposing.

title: DcpInstancesAnnotation

author: mitchdenny
body:
We would like the ability for developers, using the `aspire` CLI to be able to execute `aspire logs [resource name]`. This would result in the logs that would normally appear in the dashboard appearing in the console log.

The problem we need to solve is how does `aspire logs [resource name]` identify and connect to the apphost which is managing the resource. 

At the moment we have an RPC mechanism where the `aspire` CLI itself listens of a connection on a unix socket (the apphost initiates the connection). Should we reverse the handshake here and connect the other way? Should each app host create a socket in a well known path which the CLI can use the find the right apphost?

What security concerns are there here?

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
One thing we could do is have the AppHost write a file in a well known directory with metadata that the CLI can use. That metadata would have information such as where the project file is located, and what the path to the socket is.

If there are multiple apphosts running at once, then the CLI could actually prompt the user to ask which one to connect to (show the csproj path and the PID).

This could actually be useful for testing scenarios as well because if you have a hung test, you could use the aspire CLI to inspect the state (and DevKit extension / VS / other IDEs could enrich the experience too).

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
This would be really useful for CI too - retrofitting aspire into an existing pipeline test suite, or for using aspire with a non .net test suite. 
```
aspire run
npm test
aspire logs
```

Maybe also have an option to output logs to files (with one file per resource) rather than / as well as dumping to console which could make later analysis a lot easier than interleaved console logs for longer test runs

title: Add an `aspire logs [resource resource]` command

author: JamesNK
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

WaitFor prevents a resource waiting on itself. But it doesn't prevent a circular reference of resources waiting on each other. The resources hang in a waiting state.

You can click the `Start` action on one of the resources in a loop to start a resource, and then other resources are able to startup, but it's still an odd thing to configure. If you wanted that behavior then the right way to do it is have resources waiting on a resource with explicit start configured.

### Expected Behavior

Throw error on startup. This is already done on detection of a circular references of parent resource relationships.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_
title: WaitFor circular reference

author: tdhatcher
body:
## Background and Motivation
If an Aspire `AppHost` needs to particular sequence involving a Node script, this can be problematic.

Allow the state of a resource that is effectively a watch process without an exit to be affected by output text. The desired capability is similar to [`problemMatcher` in VS Code tasks that define an "endsPattern"](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks#_background-watching-tasks)

Today if you run a Node app (eg. `ng serve`) it seems to prematurely indicate "readiness" while it's still executing. Any output indicating "readiness" is highly variable in nature due to script customizations and frameworks.

## Proposed API

`IResourceBuilder<T>` extension

`WaitFor(IResourceBuilder<IResource> dependency, string message)`
`WaitForWithMessage(IResourceBuilder<IResource> dependency, string message)`

## Usage Examples

```csharp
// ng serve / watch
var angularClient = builder.AddNpmApp("client", "./apps/client1", "start");

// something to run only after npm project ready
var otherThing = builder.AddNpmApp("otherThing", "./apps/client2", "start")
    .WaitForWithMessage(angularClient, "bundle generation complete");
```

## Alternative Designs

## Risks

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: As an alternative you can add a http health check to your npm app.

nodes.author: CZEMacLeod
nodes.body:
I am doing something pretty close to this in my testing for [DebuggerAttach for Node](https://github.com/CZEMacLeod/C3D.Extensions.Aspire.IISExpress/tree/nodejs/src/C3D/Extensions/Aspire/Node) and refactored it out a bit.
I will probably make a package out of it, if anyone would find it useful.

https://github.com/CZEMacLeod/AspireWaitForConsoleOutput

nodes.author: tdhatcher
nodes.body: @davidfowl that would just be too easy 😁. I will give that a try. That probably helped me solve another minor issue as well with a hashicorp/vault container waiting for it to be unsealed before its ready.

nodes.author: CZEMacLeod

title: WaitFor compatibility with Node watch processes (non-exiting background process)

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: This test looks pretty racy, @DamianEdwards feels like we should rewrite or delete this test or add new apis to make it possible to write something more reliable.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Hmmm yeah, maybe it's as simple as changing the test to wait for the first resource notification after the state changes to running, but even typing that out now it still sounds like it'd be racy. Maybe we should be calculating the notification payload and including it in the event context before it gets published so stuff like this is more deterministic.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: Why not just set a TCS in the update state callback and then put a wait timeout on that.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
@mitchdenny 

>Why not just set a TCS in the update state callback and then put a wait timeout on that.

From the comments above the resource is successfully transitioning to the "Running" state, it's the waiting on command state to change to enabled that's timing out. The test simply watches all resource notifications until the state of the command of interest is enabled, after the resource enters the running state.

Which "update state callback" were you referring to exactly?

title: WithHttpCommand_EnablesCommandOnceResourceIsRunning flaky

author: bgelens
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

container images can have a healthchecks provided https://docs.docker.com/reference/dockerfile/#healthcheck

when the container is started, docker will call it and make the state available like so:

```
docker inspect --format='{{json .State.Health}}' 56c0067882aa
{"Status":"healthy","FailingStreak":0,"Log":[{"Start":"2025-03-20T10:08:53.524705545Z","End":"2025-03-20T10:08:53.588649253Z","ExitCode":0,"Output":""},{"Start":"2025-03-20T10:09:23.592720711Z","End":"2025-03-20T10:09:23.643875336Z","ExitCode":0,"Output":""},{"Start":"2025-03-20T10:09:53.646527211Z","End":"2025-03-20T10:09:53.695310628Z","ExitCode":0,"Output":""},{"Start":"2025-03-20T10:10:23.696539837Z","End":"2025-03-20T10:10:23.742670003Z","ExitCode":0,"Output":""},{"Start":"2025-03-20T10:10:53.745960878Z","End":"2025-03-20T10:10:53.795057462Z","ExitCode":0,"Output":""}]}
```

when a healthchecks is made available like this, it is executable based (no http endpoint available)

### Describe the solution you'd like

it would be really nice if Aspire could support these docker provided healthchecks natively or allow Aspire healthchecks that call into the container executables themselves.

I investigated a little bit and it is pretty hard to get the container id or name from Aspire due to DcpInstancesAnnotation being internal. 

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @danegsta this is supported in dcp right? We just need to expose it?

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
@davidfowl 

I think there’s two different scenarios here:

1. The Docker healthcheck functionality

We don’t currently expose the detailed status from the Docker managed health checks, but it makes sense to add that. I’ll open a work item. 

2. Aspire health checks that execute in a container

We do have a container exec model in place that can be integrated with the existing Aspire health checks.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Seems like we could marry the 2

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: I think we also want these to run when publishing to docker compose.

title: Support docker healthchecks

author: gabynevada
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Our team uses main codespaces for an easy 1 click development enviroment. Asipre has been great so far but we still get daily hicups which forces us to destroy and recreate the codespace, sometimes multiple times per day.

I'll create a separate issue for the problems we're getting. Other issue at #8244.

This one happens when during the day the vscode client that's running the codespace might have to be reloaded (Internet loss, codespace timeout, vscode update, etc), when connecting back to the codespace sometimes the Aspire processes never stopped but you don't have the debug controls available for the Aspire project.

In this case when you start the AppHost you get

```
 System.IO.IOException: Failed to bind to address https://127.0.0.1:22010: address already in use.
```

The process to start the App host crashes and all the silent processes keep running. Then the only options to fix this is to hunt down all the aspire processes to kill them or destroy and create the codespace again.

We ended up having to create a command alias 'killaspire' to look up all the processes for aspire and our projects and kill them so that we don't have to recreate the codespace so often.

In this issue, no processes show on the VsCode debug call stack

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/553dcf5b-9cd4-472d-9f92-fd8df26d2d74)

You get no debug controls but you can see the processes running on the "Ports" section


![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7ef4e5b2-bec6-4ffd-864e-cb2adc1688e4)



### Expected Behavior

If the vscode window is reloaded, it should either:
- Ideally show the current process Debug controls if it's still running.
- Or the prior Aspire processes be terminated when we run the App Host again



### Steps To Reproduce

Left all my devcontainer config in #8244 

For this issue I managed to replicate it by:

1. Running the App Host
2. Force closing the VsCode window to simulate a reload or internet loss conectivity
3. Connecting the codespace again via the VsCode client (At this point in the ports section you can see all of the running processes)
4. Running the AppHost again to see the port already in use errors.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
Thanks for reporting this issue. 

What is the recovery process that you use when you get into this situation? Are you killing the apphost (which would result in everything else getting shut down?).

We are thinking about what the least surprising thing for us to do here would be to smooth over this experience. If we could detect that the codespace frontend was disconnected for any period of time, perhaps we could have the AppHost self terminate - but I'm not sure if that would be surprising or not.

nodes.author: gabynevada
nodes.body:
Thanks for the quick follow up!

> What is the recovery process that you use when you get into this situation? Are you killing the apphost (which would result in everything else getting shut down?).

Yes if we kill the apphost we can recover and keep using the same codespace.


> We are thinking about what the least surprising thing for us to do here would be to smooth over this experience. If we could detect that the codespace frontend was disconnected for any period of time, perhaps we could have the AppHost self terminate - but I'm not sure if that would be surprising or not.

Based on my testing, if I reload VsCode or close it normally it will properly end the debug session and close terminate the processes.

It would definitely keep things consistent if the AppHost self terminates if it detects the codespace frontend was disconnected.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: Looks like the "old" copy of the AppHost is being left around, so the port is in use. Does not seem like an orchestration issue--but let us know if you learn otherwise!

nodes.author: dkattan
nodes.body:
I'm having this issue on MacOS with Aspire 9.2

I've looked at the other issues with dcp and the workaround that kills dcpctrl doesn't fix it. The manual fix is to use `lsof -i :22044` to identify the pid and `kill -9 22044` but it's really annoying. It's the old app host process getting left running after the debugger detaches.

title: Can't reach docker container services through service discovery

author: afscrome
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

If a failure occurs whilst pulling an image (e.g. incorrect image name, tag doesn't exist, authentication failures), no logs show up in the console logs

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d11125e2-ad06-4507-9920-506290372511)

Secondly, it takes Aspire a surprisingly long time to move from `Starting` to `Failed to start` state.  `docker run mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/does/not/exist:latest` takes me roughly 300ms.  Aspire takes 10+seconds before failing.


### Expected Behavior

I'd expect to see the error you get if you do `docker run mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/does/not/exist:latest`

```
Unable to find image 'mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/does/not/exist:latest' locally
Error response from daemon: manifest for mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/does/not/exist:latest not found: manifest unknown: manifest tagged by "latest" is not found
``` 

I'd also expect the container to move to `FailedToStart` state almost instantly (i.e. similar time to `docker run` takes to fail)

### Steps To Reproduce

```cs
    builder.AddContainer($"quick-exit", "mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/runtime-deps", "9.0");
```

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

Reproed using daily builds

```xml
  <Sdk Name="Aspire.AppHost.Sdk" Version="9.2.0-preview.1.25176.5" />
  <PackageReference Include="Aspire.Hosting.AppHost" Version="9.2.0-preview.1.25176.5" />
```


### Anything else?

Interestingly if you restart the app from the console logs page, the logs do show up
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eb9d0d56-b093-4430-b221-1000b85a33f7)

But they do not if you restart from the resource list on the homepage
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4bb053ff-6e48-4e66-8899-8c40e885fae2)


This scenario also produces an odd error in the AppHost console

```
fail: Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.dcpctrl.ContainerReconciler[0]
      could not create the container    {"Container": {"name":"nonexist0-dnueesrv"}, "Reconciliation": 9, "ContainerName": "nonexist0-dnueesrv", "error": "object not found\ncontainer not found\ndocker command 'CreateContainer' returned with non-zero exit code 1: command output: Stdout: '' Stderr: ''"}
```

"could not create the container" failing because of "container not found" is a bit circular. The container creation should have standard output or error, so I'd expect hte `Stdout` or `Stderr` fields in the error to contain something (` Unable to find image...`).  Seems to me like DCP isn't fully detecting the initial container creation error, and is then falling back to some form of timeout.

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body:
I think this is an improvement for the host. The dashboard already supports displaying whatever is written to the resource logger in the app host (for example, logs for starting and stopping a resource via commands).

The host needs to watch for an error when the container is starting up and write a message to the logs. The dashboard then automatically displays whatever is written.

title: No error logs if pulling a bad image name (+ other weird behaviour)

author: ErikEJ
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

When using RunAsContainer with SQL Database projects hosting extension, events do not seem to be respected.


```csharp
var sqlSrv = builder.AddAzureSqlServer("sql")
    .RunAsContainer();    

var sqlDb = sqlSrv.AddDatabase("aspiretodo");

var dbPrj = builder.AddSqlProject<Projects.TodoDB>("tododb")    
    .WithReference(sqlDb);
```

this code in the SQL database projects extension runs without any waiting:

```
builder.ApplicationBuilder.Eventing.Subscribe<AfterResourcesCreatedEvent>(async (@event, ct) => {
    await RunPublish(builder, target, targetDatabaseName, @event.Services, ct);
});
```
If the RunAsContainer method was updated for eventing, I think this would work out of the box with the current implementation

See discussion in the issue here: https://github.com/CommunityToolkit/Aspire/issues/529#issuecomment-2748805879

### Expected Behavior

The RunAsContainer method should fire ResourcesCreatedEvent when running.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

.NET 8

### Anything else?

```xml
<PackageReference Include="Aspire.Hosting.AppHost" Version="9.1.0" />
<PackageReference Include="Aspire.Hosting.Azure.Sql" Version="9.1.0" />
<PackageReference Include="Aspire.Hosting.SqlServer" Version="9.1.0" />
<PackageReference Include="CommunityToolkit.Aspire.Hosting.SqlDatabaseProjects" Version="9.2.1" />
```

This resource should be replacing the existing resource with a parameter resource, but instead it swaps the manifest publisher. This doesn't work outside of the manifest publisher as there's no parameter resource object.

Found while app building.

author: b-enigma-con
body:
I would like to create a custom resource implementation for an already existing application of which we can't adjust the code currently. In the appsettings, the connectionstring is defined as follows: 

```
  "TargetEndpoint": {
    "Host": "xxx",
    "Port": 1234,
    "UserName": "xxx",
    "Password": "xxx"
  },
```
How would I be able to map the injected connectionstring to these environment variables? I don't seem to be able to intercept the "discovered" connectionstring or any of its parts (scheme, port, host etc.).

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body: Take a look at https://github.com/dotnet/docs-aspire/issues/2340#issuecomment-2566057406 - that should explain how to reference individual components of endpoints in environment variables.

nodes.author: b-enigma-con
davidfowl
nodes.body:
> then the "REDIS_HOST" is resolved to value "localhost". I would have expected this to resolve to the hostname of the target container ("redis" in this case). The application which requires the alternative connectionstring settings is running from a container, so 'localhost" would not point to the correct container. Could this be a bug?

It doesn't because the project does not run inside of a container. When your project talks to redis, it is using the host network, not the container network hence localhost.

> Both RabbitMQ and my service (which should connect to RabbitMQ) run from a container, but it does not seem to resolve (container to container) properly.

If you could share something runnable or more code, we can help debug. 

> Also, the RabbitMQ integration also contains a username and password in the connectionstring, which is not part of the properties (endpoint.Property(EndpointProperty.XXX)). How would I be able to get the username and password?

Right, it's another property https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/e5648453d89e09ab7a226115b48aaab5ecf48920/src/Aspire.Hosting.RabbitMQ/RabbitMQServerResource.cs#L35-L48 (you can look at the source or the API docs https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/aspire.hosting.applicationmodel.rabbitmqserverresource?view=dotnet-aspire-8.0#properties.

> If I could retrieve the full connectionstring then I might be able to parse it and then put the parts in environment variables (which is a terrible solution, but good enough to bridge this for now in a development situation).. Only host and port is not enough in this case, I would like to have the username and password part of the connection string as well...

All of the properties are exposed (see my previous comment).

Though we try out best to make sure you fall into the happy path, this is something that still isn't as easy to use as it could be.

nodes.author: b-enigma-con
nodes.body:
> > then the "REDIS_HOST" is resolved to value "localhost". I would have expected this to resolve to the hostname of the target container ("redis" in this case). The application which requires the alternative connectionstring settings is running from a container, so 'localhost" would not point to the correct container. Could this be a bug?
> 
> It doesn't because the project does not run inside of a container. When your project talks to redis, it is using the host network, not the container network hence localhost.
> 

I meant that I adjusted the example to my situation, which is 2 containers refering to each other. I created a bug report for this: issue #8574.

I understand and appreciate that. Thank you for your suggestion, I will try to find the other properties for retrieving username & password later this week.

title: Transform connectionstring to multiple env. vars

author: eerhardt
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

This code 

https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/f9035bc913df62c51ead803f0578518f53b0364a/src/Aspire.Hosting/Publishing/ManifestPublishingContext.cs#L593-L619

claims it is possible to not have a name on a volume.

However, the `name` property is marked as `required` in the manifest schema.

https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/c29004a2da959df39a08b303733b19f4b3961dee/src/Schema/aspire-8.0.json#L670-L675

We need to resolve this discrepancy. Either names are required, or they aren't.

### Expected Behavior

_No response_

### Steps To Reproduce

```c#
var redis = builder.AddRedis("cache")
    .WithVolume("/data");
```

Produces manifest:

```json
 "cache": {
      "type": "container.v0",
      "connectionString": "{cache.bindings.tcp.host}:{cache.bindings.tcp.port},password={cache-password.value}",
      "image": "docker.io/library/redis:7.4",
      "entrypoint": "/bin/sh",
      "args": [
        "-c",
        "redis-server --requirepass $REDIS_PASSWORD"
      ],
      "volumes": [
        {
          "target": "/data",
          "readOnly": false
        }
      ],
      "env": {
        "REDIS_PASSWORD": "{cache-password.value}"
      },
      "bindings": {
        "tcp": {
          "scheme": "tcp",
          "protocol": "tcp",
          "transport": "tcp",
          "targetPort": 6379
        }
      }
    },
```

Which doesn't pass our manifest schema validation

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

cc @mitchdenny @davidfowl @DamianEdwards @vhvb1989

nodes.author: vhvb1989
nodes.body:
Can you make `.WithVolume(...);` to automatically set a default name if it is not provided by the user?

I assume the builder has access to the name of the resource where the volume is added, so you can use that name and some suffix like `<resourceName>-vol-<index>`

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
> Can you make .WithVolume(...); to automatically set a default name if it is not provided by the user?

The intention of this API is to use an anonymous volume.

https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/f9035bc913df62c51ead803f0578518f53b0364a/src/Aspire.Hosting/ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.cs#L89-L120

Giving it a name kind of defeats the purpose.

nodes.author: vhvb1989
nodes.body:
Is anonymous ==  unnamed?  

Should the name of an anonymous volume be something like `anonymous-vol-for-resouce-01` ?

Taking the next doc from copilot about Dotnet compiler:

> When debugging in C#, anonymous functions are typically given internally generated names by the compiler to help the debugger reference and display them. These names are not part of the code you write—they're metadata added during compilation to allow tools like Visual Studio to handle anonymous functions effectively

Can we follow the same and make Aspire publisher to use internal generated names for the manifest/Azure?

title: Volume names required in manifest, but not always written in code

author: claudiaregio
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Feedback from user study: 

The syntax for adding dependencies in the apphost can get too long and verbose when needed to add more than a few services. 

**Also worth noting this user was not able to recognize use cases where .WithReference and .WaitFor would need to be separate** 

### Describe the solution you'd like

If there are multiple instances of services they want connected, user wanted to see: 

`builder.AddDependencies(frontend, backendAPI);` 
OR
`builder.AddDependencies(backendAPI, redisCache,postgresDatabase);` 

INSTEAD OF 

```
builder.AddProject("frontend")    
    .WithReference(backendAPI)    
    .WaitFor(backendAPI);    
    .WithReference(postgresDatabase)    
    .WaitFor(postgresDatabase)    
    .WithReference(redisCache)    
    .WaitFor(redisCache)    
```

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: We've been talking about adding a new `WithReferences` method that can accept multiple resources to reference, along with a `WaitFor` overload that accepts multiple resources. I'm not keen on the `AddDependencies` method name as the `Add` prefix is reserved for methods that add resources to the model, but perhaps a `WithDependencies` that does both `WithReference` and `WaitFor` could be considered?

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards I like that. even just starting with a "WithReferences" and WaitFor([ ]) would be enough for most I bet. I would love to know how many people add references that they don't wait for - my assumption is most reference but dont wait, because otherwise you end up with a really sequential startup and that would make it slower? But maybe that doesn't matter if the apphost can stay living for so long?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
> my assumption is most reference but dont wait, because otherwise you end up with a really sequential startup and that would make it slower? 

It does indeed make it slower overall, and obviously the more you add in a wait for "chain", the longer it takes. It's also important to enable separating `WithReference` from `WaitFor` for cases where you need the reference to get connection info injected, but are resilient to the reference not being available (you know, like a good cloud-native app should be 😉).

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body:
> > my assumption is most reference but dont wait, because otherwise you end up with a really sequential startup and that would make it slower?
> 
> It does indeed make it slower overall, and obviously the more you add in a wait for "chain", the longer it takes. It's also important to enable separating `WithReference` from `WaitFor` for cases where you need the reference to get connection info injected, but are resilient to the reference not being available (you know, like a good cloud-native app should be 😉).

Cool. Then i say we start with allowing multiples in WaitFor & add WithReferences and see if the demand still exists for WithBoth?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
Did a bit of a dive into this in the [damianedwards/MultiWithReferenceWaitFor branch](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/tree/damianedwards/MultiWithReferenceWaitFor) and the results are pretty mixed.

Introduced a new interface:

```csharp
public interface IReferenceable<in TSource, in TDestination>
    where TDestination : IResource
    where TSource : IReferenceable<TSource, TDestination>
```

which defines a static abstract method:

```csharp
static abstract void ProcessReference(TSource source, IResourceBuilder<TDestination> destination);
```

so that any type can declare it can be referenced by another type when the other type implements whatever constraints are required, e.g. updated `IResourceWithConnectionString` and `IResourceWithServiceDiscovery`:

```csharp
public interface IResourceWithConnectionString : IResource, IManifestExpressionProvider, IValueProvider, IValueWithReferences,
    IReferenceable<IResourceWithConnectionString, IResourceWithEnvironment>

public interface IResourceWithServiceDiscovery : IResourceWithEndpoints,
    IReferenceable<IResourceWithServiceDiscovery, IResourceWithEnvironment>
```

Then added overloads of a new `WithReferences` method that allows passing multiple sources that implement `IReferenceable` (there'd be N overloads of this method to support different numbers of sources):

```csharp
public static IResourceBuilder<TDestination> WithReferences<TDestination, TSource1, TSource2>(this IResourceBuilder<TDestination> builder,
    IResourceBuilder<TSource1> source1,
    IResourceBuilder<TSource2> source2)
    where TDestination : IResource
    where TSource1 : IReferenceable<TSource1, TDestination>, IResource
    where TSource2 : IReferenceable<TSource2, TDestination>, IResource
{
    TSource1.ProcessReference(source1.Resource, builder);
    TSource2.ProcessReference(source2.Resource, builder);

    return builder;
}
```

This can then be used like:

```csharp
var frontend = builder.AddProject<Projects.MyFrontend>("frontend")
                      .WithExternalHttpEndpoints()
                      .WithReferences(basketService, catalogService);
```

This works well enough for resources referencing other resources, where the only thing it needs to do is inject environment variables, but hits a wall for referencing non-resource sources, e.g. `EndpointReference`, and sources with more complicated requirements , e.g. `OrleansService` which requires the destination to implement both `IResourceWithEnvironment` and `IResourceWithEndpoints`. This is because the signature for the method requires an `IResourceBuilder<TSource>` and things like `EndpointReference` aren't resources.

I tried changing the `WithReferences` overloads to accept straight `TSourceN` typed parameters rather than `IResourceBuilder<TSourceN>` and that works, but now you need to dot into the `Resource` property when adding references to other resources, e.g.:

```csharp
var frontend = builder.AddProject<Projects.MyFrontend>("frontend")
                      .WithExternalHttpEndpoints()
                      .WithReferences(basketService.Resource, catalogService.GetEndpoint("f"))
```

I tried to make `IResourceBuilder<TResource>` support implicitly converting to `TResource` (by simply returning `this.Resource`) to resolve this but you can't implement implicit operators on interfaces.

It would be **possible** to have the enough overloads for all possible combinations of sources where a source is either an `IResourceBuilder<TSourceN>` or a non-resource `TSourceN` but that is super unwieldy (e.g. if we wanted to support up to 9 sources I think we'd need 2^9 overloads).

Even if we did want to have all those overloads, supporting overloads that support sources that have more requirements than just `IResourceWithEnvironment` for the destination is further impractical as it pushes those source types to add a generic type arg in order to define the multiple requirements as type constraints, e.g. `OrleansService` would have to become `OrleansService<TDestination> where TDestination : IResourceWithEnvironment, IResourceWithEndpoints`, which of course has viral effects.

Note, supporting an overload of `WaitFor` that accepts multiple other resources doesn't have any of these issues and could be done easily.

So, ultimately there's a few tensions working against each other here WRT supporting `WithReferences`. If we were to limit the `WithReferences` method to accepting `IResourceBuilder<TSource>` it's fairly clean, but then you can't pass things like `EndpointReference` to it. If you want it support things `EndpointReference` as sources, then you need to accept having to resolve the `Resource` property for resources you want to pass to it or have a very large number of overloads. And then it still doesn't support more complex sources like `OrleansService`.

Having `WithReferences` only support a subset of the possible sources that can otherwise be passed to an overload of `WithReference(TSource source)` seems like it would cause some confusion, e.g. "why can I pass this thing to `WithReferences` but not this other thing that I **can** pass to `WithReference`?".

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
megasoft1978
DamianEdwards
nodes.body: @megasoft1978 I think that has all the same issues RE generic constraints and resources vs. non-resources from an API design POV, right?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Moving this to the backlog as there isn't a clear way to move this forward right now.

title: More concise way of adding dependencies

author: DamianEdwards
body:
In 9.2 we added resource icons to the resources table and graph views. We should go further and enable resources to specify their own custom icons to be used when displayed in the dashboard. This should be done in such a way that hosting integrations can specify custom icons for their resources, so that, e.g., the Redis resource could show up with the Redis icon in the dashboard.

The icon itself would need to be sent from the app host resource server to the dashboard process so would need to be serializable. I imagine we'd want to support SVG which has the advantage of being vector and text-based. We could support bitmap-based formats like PNG, ICO, JPG, etc., by encoding them as data-uris.

I imagine an API kinda like the following for using a file on disk:

```csharp
builder.AddContainer("foo", "foo")
    .WithResourceIcon("./myicon.svg");
```

And perhaps something like this for something embedded, e.g. in a hosting integration:

```csharp
builder.AddContainer("foo", "foo")
    .WithResourceIcon(EncodeAsDataUri(Resources.MyIcon), ImageFormat.Png);
```

nodes.author: burtonrodman
nodes.body: maybe default to favicon where appropriate??

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Re-opening as the PR added support for specifying the name of a known icon, but not setting custom icons.

title: Allow resources to specify custom icons to use when displayed in the dashboard

title: Flaky test: Aspire.Hosting.Tests.DistributedApplicationTests.StartAsync_UnsecuredAllowAnonymous_PassedToDashboardProcess

author: radical

nodes.author: radical
RussKie
nodes.body:
To me this indicates that the test configuration needs improvement. For example, if a test known to require isolation, then it should be decorated to run in isolation. 
E.g., AFAIK, the Windows Forms team had issues with clipboard-related tests, and those were updated to run sequentially (i.e., in isolation). I believe this is how it's done: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/testing.md#sequential-collection, but we could ping the team, if necessary.

nodes.author: radical
nodes.body:
We can aim to get to that ideal state, but for now we need to work with the current state. It creates unnecessary extra work for anyone (me in particular :) tracking/fixing/quaranting-unquarantining the tests. IMHO, we should:

1. Update the current Outerloop tests workflow to run full test assemblies for any test that contains a Quarantined test.
2. Meanwhile, work on improving the tests to be better
3. Once (2) is achieved we can return to running only individual tests.

nodes.author: radical
nodes.body: Incorrectly closed by https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/9115 . Re-opening.

title: Flaky test: Aspire.Hosting.Tests.DistributedApplicationTests.VerifyExecutableStopStartWorks

author: AlpineJBoehnen
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Based on discussion https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/discussions/2069

I would like to configure CPU and memory usage in code (e.g., in `Program.cs`) for Aspire projects, without relying solely on Azure-specific or YAML-based configuration. Currently, there appears to be no built-in way to do this within Aspire itself.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Introduce an API or extension methods in Aspire that let developers specify CPU and memory limits directly in code. This approach would allow local or code-based configuration that mimics production-like settings.

### Additional context

I initially thought this might be possible using [Azure.Provisioning](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/Azure.Provisioning_1.0.0/sdk/provisioning/Azure.Provisioning/README.md), but after looking more closely, it seems Aspire does not expose CPU/memory configuration in code. Adding such functionality would greatly improve our development workflow.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
>I initially thought this might be possible using [Azure.Provisioning](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/Azure.Provisioning_1.0.0/sdk/provisioning/Azure.Provisioning/README.md), but after looking more closely, it seems Aspire does not expose CPU/memory configuration in code. Adding such functionality would greatly improve our development workflow.

https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/8000#issuecomment-2724307587

Its pretty important for cost control on Azure.

Is the way I'm doing above incorrect? it seems to work.

Yes, lets do that and we'll expose the same in the app model.

Yes, it's correct. We're discussing if we should also have the same for local development.

D'oh, I'm an idiot, sorry!

title: Allow configuration of Azure container app resource allocation in code

author: afscrome
body: ### Is there an existing issue for this? - [x] I have searched the existing issues ### Describe the bug If a file fails to copy into a container with the new Container Files API, the error shows up in the App Host console logs, but I'd expect it to show up in the resource logs on the dashboard. ### Expected Behavior ### Steps To Reproduce ```cs var redis = builder.AddRedis("redis"); redis.WithContainerFiles("/does/not/exist", [ new ContainerFile{ Name="foo", Contents ="bar" }]); ``` ### Exceptions (if any) ``` fail: Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.dcpctrl.ContainerReconciler[0] could not copy file to the container {"Container": {"name":"redis-pkxjdztq"}, "Reconciliation": 11, "ContainerName": "redis-pkxjdztq", "ContainerID": "e089fc5977390412cd2ce8f4cf4587d51a5a4e52c5df5415558d0f2e9bb56b7d", "Destination": "/does/not/exist", "error": "docker command 'CopyFile' returned with non-zero exit code 1: command output: Stdout: '' Stderr: 'destination \"e089fc5977390412cd2ce8f4cf4587d51a5a4e52c5df5415558d0f2e9bb56b7d:/does/not/exist\" must be a directory\n'"} ``` ### .NET Version info _No response_ ### Anything else? _No response_

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
Below is another example of DCP logs that shoudl get tied back to a resource
```
fail: Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.dcpctrl.ServiceReconciler.Proxy[0]
      Error handling TCP connection     {"Service": {"name":"web-http"}, "error": "Could not establish TCP connection to endpoint: dial tcp 127.0.0.1:56127: connectex: No connection could be made because the target machine actively refused it."}
```

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1a4da11b-9d53-42e9-8e13-cfbb517dcb33)

Repro this error with the following code, then wait about 2 mins before DCP starts reporting the error.
```cs
builder.AddProject<Projects.aspire_Web>("web")
    .WithEnvironment("DOTNET_DiagnosticPorts", "does-not-exist.sock")
    .WithHttpHealthCheck();
```

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
This has somewhat improved in 9.3.  Failures do at least stop the contaienr starting up.  Sometimes the error does show in the resource logs, but not always.

For example, the following cuases the resource to `FailedToStart`, but no details show in the resource's log on the dashboard.

```
fail: Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.dcpctrl.ContainerReconciler[0]
      could not copy files to the container     {"Container": {"name":"REDACTED-dpasrzfa"}, "Reconciliation": 46, "ContainerName": "REDACTED-dpasrzfa", "ContainerID": "aafa911e8b7944a8675887aa52e9615705aa61c391049b492d8965a45f9483d1", "Destination": "/tmp", "error": "runtime is not healthy\ndocker runtime is not healthy"}
```

title: Failure to copy file into container should show in resource logs

author: dluc
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

When running Aspire AppHost, the process validates **all** profiles in launchSettings.json, even the extra ones defined for custom dev tasks.

Given the following `launchSettings.json`

```json
{
  "$schema": "https://json.schemastore.org/launchsettings.json",
  "profiles": {
    "http": {
      "commandName": "Project",
      "dotnetRunMessages": true,
      "launchBrowser": false,
      "applicationUrl": "http://localhost:60000",
      "environmentVariables": {
        "ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development"
      }
    },
    "https": {
      "commandName": "Project",
      "dotnetRunMessages": true,
      "launchBrowser": false,
      "applicationUrl": "https://localhost:60001;http://localhost:60000",
      "environmentVariables": {
        "ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development"
      }
    },
    "debug": {
      "commandName": "Project",
      "dotnetRunMessages": true,
      "launchBrowser": false,
      "applicationUrl": "https://localhost:60001;http://localhost:60000",
      "environmentVariables": {
        "FOO": 123
      }
    }
  }
}
```


where the "debug" profile has a minor issue - "FOO" should be a string not a number - Aspire AppHost fails to start and throws an exception:

> Unhandled exception. Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplicationException: **Failed to get effective launch profile** for project resource 'MyProject'. There is **malformed JSON** in the project's launch settings file at 'MyProject/Properties/launchSettings.json'
>  ---> System.Text.Json.JsonException: **The JSON value could not be converted to System.String**. Path: $.profiles.debug.environmentVariables.FOO | LineNumber: 27 | BytePositionInLine: 20.
>  ---> System.InvalidOperationException: **Cannot get the value of a token type 'Number' as a string**.
>    at System.Text.Json.ThrowHelper.ThrowInvalidOperationException_ExpectedString(JsonTokenType tokenType)
>    at System.Text.Json.Utf8JsonReader.GetString()
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Converters.StringConverter.Read(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonConverter`1.TryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value, Boolean& isPopulatedValue)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonDictionaryConverter`3.OnTryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, TDictionary& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Converters.JsonMetadataServicesConverter`1.OnTryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonConverter`1.TryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value, Boolean& isPopulatedValue)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Metadata.JsonPropertyInfo`1.ReadJsonAndSetMember(Object obj, ReadStack& state, Utf8JsonReader& reader)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Converters.ObjectDefaultConverter`1.OnTryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Converters.JsonMetadataServicesConverter`1.OnTryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonConverter`1.TryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value, Boolean& isPopulatedValue)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonDictionaryConverter`3.OnTryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, TDictionary& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Converters.JsonMetadataServicesConverter`1.OnTryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonConverter`1.TryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value, Boolean& isPopulatedValue)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Metadata.JsonPropertyInfo`1.ReadJsonAndSetMember(Object obj, ReadStack& state, Utf8JsonReader& reader)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Converters.ObjectDefaultConverter`1.OnTryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Converters.JsonMetadataServicesConverter`1.OnTryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonConverter`1.TryRead(Utf8JsonReader& reader, Type typeToConvert, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state, T& value, Boolean& isPopulatedValue)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonConverter`1.ReadCore(Utf8JsonReader& reader, T& value, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state)
>    --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
>    at System.Text.Json.ThrowHelper.ReThrowWithPath(ReadStack& state, Utf8JsonReader& reader, Exception ex)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.JsonConverter`1.ReadCore(Utf8JsonReader& reader, T& value, JsonSerializerOptions options, ReadStack& state)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Metadata.JsonTypeInfo`1.ContinueDeserialize(ReadBufferState& bufferState, JsonReaderState& jsonReaderState, ReadStack& readStack, T& value)
>    at System.Text.Json.Serialization.Metadata.JsonTypeInfo`1.Deserialize(Stream utf8Json)
>    at System.Text.Json.JsonSerializer.Deserialize[TValue](Stream utf8Json, JsonTypeInfo`1 jsonTypeInfo)
>    at Aspire.Hosting.LaunchProfileExtensions.GetLaunchSettings(IProjectMetadata projectMetadata, String resourceName) in /_/src/Shared/LaunchProfiles/LaunchProfileExtensions.cs:line 97
>    --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
>    at Aspire.Hosting.LaunchProfileExtensions.GetLaunchSettings(IProjectMetadata projectMetadata, String resourceName) in /_/src/Shared/LaunchProfiles/LaunchProfileExtensions.cs:line 103
>    at Aspire.Hosting.LaunchProfileExtensions.GetLaunchSettings(ProjectResource projectResource) in /_/src/Shared/LaunchProfiles/LaunchProfileExtensions.cs:line 28
>    at Aspire.Hosting.LaunchProfileExtensions.TrySelectLaunchProfileFromDefaultAnnotation(ProjectResource projectResource, String& launchProfileName) in /_/src/Shared/LaunchProfiles/LaunchProfileExtensions.cs:line 138
>    at Aspire.Hosting.LaunchProfileExtensions.SelectLaunchProfileName(ProjectResource projectResource) in /_/src/Shared/LaunchProfiles/LaunchProfileExtensions.cs:line 179
>    at Aspire.Hosting.LaunchProfileExtensions.GetEffectiveLaunchProfile(ProjectResource projectResource, Boolean throwIfNotFound) in /_/src/Shared/LaunchProfiles/LaunchProfileExtensions.cs:line 33
>    at Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.WithProjectDefaults(IResourceBuilder`1 builder, ProjectResourceOptions options) in /_/src/Aspire.Hosting/ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.cs:line 341
>    at Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.AddProject(IDistributedApplicationBuilder builder, String name, String projectPath, Action`1 configure) in /_/src/Aspire.Hosting/ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.cs:line 282
>    at Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.AddProject(IDistributedApplicationBuilder builder, String name, String projectPath) in /_/src/Aspire.Hosting/ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.cs:line 100

### Expected Behavior

While the error is ok-ish, there is no reason to validate every profile in launchSettings.json, is there? It seems a waste of resources, and AppHost should just start if the profile selected is fine, ignoring other profiles.

Outside the scope of this issue: the env var parser could be improved, just taking the number as a string, like bash vars and .env files work.

### Steps To Reproduce

Add a profile with an env var where the value is a number.

### .NET Version info

.NET 9
Aspire 9.1

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: I don't think this is a bug, just fix the malformed JSON 😄

nodes.author: dluc
nodes.body: To be fair the json is not malformed, I mean it's valid JSON. The "profile" is malformed but just because .NET is being pedantic about env vars 😉

title: Flaky test: Aspire.Hosting.Tests.DistributedApplicationTests.SpecifyingEnvPortInEndpointFlowsToEnv

author: mip1983
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Since Aspire 9.2 when running locally I've been hitting issues where it starts complaining of duplicate keys in secrets.json (for the AppHost).

e.g.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f8cdd7b4-2183-4fd6-940a-b1d6fbdd29f4)

When I go to look at the file, both the formatting has been changed and duplicate keys created.

So if the json was previously:

Format 1:
```json
"Azure" : {
     "Tenant": "somevalue"
     etc...
}
```

This ends up as 

Format 2:
```json
"Azure:Tenant": "somevalue"
```

Sometimes it generates a mixture of the two formats with the duplicate keys.

If I delete the contents of the file leaving just the connection string to an external SQL resource and press f5, it will regenerate the file again, reformatting my existing settings as 'Format 2' above, and generates new settings with 'Format 1'. But if you stop debugging and start again, it all gets regenerated as 'Format 2'. It's when you go to add new resources again after that, that it seems to get a mixture of formats and duplicate keys.



### Expected Behavior

secrets.json format should be consistent, and probably stay as 'Format 1' from the description above.

### Steps To Reproduce

Create an aspire project. Configure your Azure subscription id, resource group and location in appsettings.json of AppHost.

Connect to an existing sql resource with a connection string e.g. builder.AddConnectionString, and put this connection string in secrets.json.

Connect other Azure resources like storage, configuring them in apphost, e.g. builder.AddAzureStorage.

Run the project with F5 and see if secrets.json gets mangled or duplications with each step above.

### Exceptions (if any)

Duplicate key exception for secrets.json

title: AppHost secrets.json Gets reformatted/inconsistent formatting with duplicate keys breaking local dev

author: davidfowl
body:
Today every concrete resource class—`ProjectResource`, `ContainerResource`, `AzureServiceBusResource`, etc.—owns state in its own fields.  
When real workflows demand the **same logical resource** appear differently in run-mode and publish-mode, our **model** currently must

1. **remove** the original resource instance  
2. **create** another concrete type  
3. **copy** annotations by hand  

That breaks identity (two resource IDs), scatters logs, confuses diff tooling, and forces hacks inside helpers such as `RunAsContainer()`, `RunAsEmulator()`, and `PublishAsDockerFile()`.

We _already_ tie container identity to the **annotation-collection reference**; this proposal finishes that idea for **all** resources:

* **All observable state lives in the annotation collection.**
* A discriminator annotation — `ResourceTypeAnnotation.ResourceKind : Type` — declares the *current* shape.
* Wrapper classes (*views*) expose ergonomic APIs but share the same annotation spine.

| Dev inner-loop | Publish output |
| -------------- | -------------- |
| `.NET Project` | OCI **container** |
| **Emulator container** | **Azure PaaS** service |
| Local **Redis container** | **Connection-string parameter** pointing at a shared cache |

Identity never changes; we simply switch the **tag**.

```mermaid
graph TD
    subgraph "Annotations (identity)"
        A["{ annotations … ; tag = ResourceKind }"]
    end
    A -- viewed-as --> B[ProjectResource]
    A -- viewed-as --> C[ContainerResource]
    A -- viewed-as --> D[AzureBicepResource]
    A -- viewed-as --> E[ConnectionStringParam]
```

### Code sketches (same helpers, new engine)

```csharp
// Project ⇒ container on publish
builder.AddProject("web")
       .PublishAsDockerFile(); // internally retags to ContainerResource

// Azure PaaS ⇒ emulator container on local run
builder.AddAzureServiceBus("events")
       .RunAsEmulator();      // retags to ContainerResource

// Container ⇒ external hosted cache for prod
builder.AddRedis("cache")
       .PublishAsConnectionString(); // retags to ConnectionStringParameter
```

---

## Execution plan (high-level)

**Phase A — helper façade**  
* Add `IsKind<T>()`, `TryGet<T>()` (initial impl = `is/as`).  
* Replace direct `is`, `as`, `OfType<T>()` in the codebase.  
* Roslyn analyzer forbids new violations.  
* _Behaviour identical to today._

**Phase B — tag & identity**  
* Introduce `ResourceTypeAnnotation` and `Resource.ResourceKind`.  
* `Equals`/`GetHashCode` now rely on the annotation-collection reference.  
* Helpers switch to the tag internally.  
* _Identity stable across view switches._

**Phase C — move data to annotations**  
* Create `*Annotation` classes (e.g. `ContainerEntryPointAnnotation`).  
* Properties wrap annotations; helpers retag instead of delete + clone.  

Annotation collections become read-only after model-build; cloning must be explicit.

---

## Helper API details

```csharp
public static bool IsKind<T>(this IResource r)
    => r.ResourceKind == typeof(T);

public static bool TryGet<T>(this IResource r,
                             [NotNullWhen(true)] out T? view)
    where T : class, IResource
{
    if (r.ResourceKind == typeof(T))
    {
        view = r as T ??
               (T)Activator.CreateInstance(typeof(T), r.Name, r.Annotations)!;
        return true;
    }
    view = null;
    return false;
}
```

*Every resource kind must expose a `(string name, ResourceAnnotationCollection ann)` constructor; an analyzer will enforce this.*

---

## Trade-offs & potential issues

* **Exhaustiveness** – compiler no longer warns if a new kind is unhandled.  
  _Mitigation_: default branches plus analyzer checks.  
* **Performance** – reflection in the helpers.  
  _Mitigation_: cache `typeof(T)` comparisons and profile.  
* **External extensions using `is/as`** – will break when the tag diverges from CLR type.  
  _Mitigation_: analyzer package + migration docs; optional runtime guard.  
* **Annotation mutability** – copy-on-write or concurrent edits could corrupt identity.  
  _Mitigation_: freeze collection reference after build; mutations through `WithAnnotation`.  
* **Constructor convention** – new kinds must add the two-arg ctor.  
  _Mitigation_: analyzer + project template.  
* **Versioning** – equality semantics change.  
  _Mitigation_: land in next major release; debug shim to detect old behaviour.  

---

## Unsolved / open design gaps

**View-specific members remain callable after a view switch.**

Example: you create an `AzureBicepResource`, call `RunAsEmulator()`, so it is now viewed as a container, yet `bicepResource.Outputs["primaryKey"]` is still accessible—even though those outputs are meaningless in run-mode.

Unanswered questions:

* Do we introduce **publish-only / run-only capabilities** so annotations can self-describe validity?  
* Should runtime guards throw (or assert) when a publish-only member is accessed under a run-mode tag?  
* Can a Roslyn analyzer warn when publish-only members are used in run-time code paths?  
* At minimum we need docs that state: after a view switch certain members are undefined and accessing them is user error.

These remain open and must be tracked as follow-up work once the union mechanics are in place.

See https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/7251 for an initial prototype
